text: The tech entrepreneur and close adviser to Donald Trump Elon Musk has taken a stunning new public step in his support for the far-right German political party Alternative for Germany (AfD), publishing a supportive guest opinion piece for the country’s Welt am Sonntag newspaper that has prompted the commentary editor to resign in protest. The commentary piece in German was launched online on Saturday before being published on Sunday in the flagship paper of the Axel Springer media group, which also owns the US politics news site Politico. Musk uses populist and personal language to try to deny AfD’s extremist bent, and the essay expands on his post on his social media platform, X, on which he last week claimed that “only the AfD can save Germany”. Translated, Musk’s piece said: “The portrayal of the AfD as rightwing extremist is clearly false, considering that Alice Weidel, the party’s leader, has a same-sex partner from Sri Lanka! Does that sound like Hitler to you? Please!” Germany’s domestic intelligence agency has classified the AfD at the national level as a suspected extremism case since 2021. Shortly after the piece was published online, the editor of the opinion section, Eva Marie Kogel, used the US tech mogul’s own platform to post on X that she had submitted her resignation. “I always enjoyed heading the opinion department at Welt and Wams. Today a text by Elon Musk appeared in Welt am Sonntag. Yesterday I submitted my resignation after printing,” she posted. She included a link to the Musk commentary article. The AfD has a strong anti-immigration stance and, like incoming president Donald Trump in relation to the US, is calling for mass deportations from Germany. Earlier in December, Musk not only posted in favor of AfD but the party’s hard line on immigration appeared to resonate with the incoming US vice-president, JD Vance, MSNBC reported. Senior Welt Group figures weighed in on Saturday. “Democracy and journalism thrive on freedom of expression.
b1_text:
Elon Musk is a tech boss and helps Donald Trump. He has done something new that supports a German political party. This party is called Alternative for Germany (AfD).

Musk wrote an article for a German newspaper, Welt am Sonntag. The editor of the newspaper's opinion section did not like this. She quit her job because of Musk's article.

The article was in German. It was online on Saturday and in the newspaper on Sunday. The newspaper is owned by a big media company. This company also owns the news site Politico.

Musk wrote that AfD is not extreme. He said Alice Weidel, the leader of AfD, has a partner who is from Sri Lanka. Her partner is also the same sex as her. Musk asked if this sounds like Hitler.

Germany's intelligence agency thinks AfD might be extremist. They have been watching AfD since 2021.

Eva Marie Kogel was the editor of the opinion section. She used Musk's social media site, X, to say she quit. She said she liked her job, but she resigned after Musk's article was printed. She shared a link to Musk's article.

AfD does not want many immigrants in Germany. They want to send many people out of Germany. Donald Trump wants to do something similar in the US.

In December, Musk said he liked AfD. JD Vance, who might be the next US vice-president, seemed to agree with AfD about immigration.

Some important people at the Welt Group talked about the situation on Saturday. They said freedom of speech is important for democracy and journalism.

text: This includes dealing with polarising positions and classifying them journalistically,” the newspaper’s editor-in-chief designate, Jan Philipp Burgard, and Ulf Poschardt, who takes over as publisher on 1 January, told Reuters. They said discussion about Musk’s piece, which had about 340 comments several hours after it was published, was “very revealing”. Underneath Musk’s commentary, the newspaper published a response by Burgard. “Musk’s diagnosis is correct, but his therapeutic approach, that only the AfD can save Germany, is fatally false,” he wrote, referencing the AfD’s desire to leave the European Union and seek rapprochement with Russia as well as appease China. Musk and Weidel both later posted a link to the article on X. The AfD backing from Musk, who also defended his right to weigh in on German politics due to his “significant investments”, comes as Germans are set to vote on 23 February after a coalition government led by the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, collapsed late this fall. The AfD is running second in opinion polls and might be able to thwart either a centre-right or centre-left majority, but Germany’s mainstream, more centrist parties have pledged to shun any support from the AfD at the national level.
b1_text:
The new leaders of a newspaper told Reuters about a story about Elon Musk. The leaders are Jan Philipp Burgard and Ulf Poschardt. Jan Philipp Burgard will be the editor. Ulf Poschardt will be the publisher. He starts on January 1.

The story about Musk had many comments. The leaders said the discussion about the story showed a lot.

The newspaper also printed a reply from Burgard after Musk's words. Burgard said Musk was right about a problem. But Burgard said Musk's idea for fixing it was wrong. Musk thought the AfD party could save Germany. Burgard said this was not right. He mentioned the AfD wants to leave the European Union and be friendly with Russia and China.

Musk and Alice Weidel later shared a link to the story on X.

Musk said he can talk about German politics. He said he has a lot of money invested there. The AfD party has Musk's support.

Germans will vote on February 23. The government of Olaf Scholz ended recently. The AfD party is doing well in the polls. They might stop the center-right or center-left from winning. But the main parties in Germany said they will not work with the AfD.

text: Dominique Pelicot will not appeal against his conviction for drugging and raping his wife and inviting strangers to rape her, his lawyer has said. Béatrice Zavarro said the former electrician, 72, who was jailed for the maximum 20 years this month, wished to spare his now ex-wife, Gisèle Pelicot, a new ordeal but admitted there was also the risk a new trial in front of a public jury could mean a longer prison sentence. Pelicot and the 50 others who were all found guilty of rape or sexual assault after a three-and-a-half-month trial have until midnight on Monday to lodge an appeal. A statement from public prosecutor confirmed that 17 people had so far appealed against their convictions, adding that a new trial would be held in Nîmes towards the end of next year. Gisèle Pelicot, 72, a retired logistics manager, believes she may have been raped more than 200 times by her husband and other men between 2011 and 2020, when Dominique Pelicot was finally caught after filming up the skirts of female shoppers in a supermarket near the couple’s home in the Provençal town of Mazan. Detectives subsequently found tens of thousands of videos of the abuse on his phone and a hard drive. On Monday, Zavarro said Dominique Pelicot had decided not to appeal against his conviction because to do so would “force Gisèle into a new ordeal and new confrontations, which [he] rejects”. Appealing against the guilty judgment, when Pelicot admitted the charges, would involve “running an unnecessary risk”, she added, as the accusations could be made more serious in the appeal court, where the case would be held in front of a public jury, potentially leading to a longer prison term. “It is time to put an end to this judicially,” Zavarro said on Monday. The marathon rape trial in Avignon was heard by a panel of five professional magistrates. The appeal court, which sits in the southern city of Nîmes, will require a new full trial within the next year. Gisèle Pelicot is not required to attend the appeal hearing but her lawyer, Stéphane Babonneau, indicated she was ready to do so.
b1_text:
Dominique Pelicot was found guilty. He drugged and hurt his wife. He also invited strangers to hurt her. His lawyer said he will not ask for a new trial.

The man, who is 72 years old, used to work as an electrician. He was sent to prison for 20 years. This is the longest time he could be in prison for his crimes.

His lawyer, Béatrice Zavarro, said that Dominique does not want to cause more pain to his ex-wife, Gisèle Pelicot. She also said that if there was a new trial, he could get an even longer prison sentence.

Dominique and 50 other people were found guilty. They hurt Gisèle. The trial lasted for three and a half months. They have until Monday night to ask for a new trial.

A statement said that 17 people have asked for a new trial. The new trial will be in Nîmes next year.

Gisèle Pelicot is also 72 years old. She used to work as a manager. She thinks she was hurt more than 200 times by her husband and other men. This happened between 2011 and 2020.

Dominique was caught when he took videos of women in a shop. This shop was near their home in Mazan. Mazan is a town in France.

The police found many videos on his phone. The videos showed the abuse.

On Monday, Béatrice Zavarro said that Dominique decided not to ask for a new trial. He does not want to make Gisèle suffer again. He also does not want to risk a longer prison time.

She said that if he asked for a new trial, the case could become more serious. This is because the new trial would be in front of a jury. A jury is a group of people who decide if someone is guilty. If the jury thinks he is very guilty, he could stay in prison longer.

Béatrice Zavarro said it is time for the case to end.

The first trial was in Avignon. Five judges listened to the case. The new trial in Nîmes will take place next year.

Gisèle does not have to go to the new trial. But her lawyer, Stéphane Babonneau, said she is ready to go if she needs to.

text: “She has told us she will be there. Maybe not every day but she says she will go,” he said. She became an international feminist figurehead after insisting the trial be held in open court and the videos of her abuse shown in order that “shame changes sides”. The trial has caused much soul-searcing in France and calls to tighten French rape laws, including introducing the concept of “consent”, which is absent. The trial also threw a spotlight on attitudes towards the rape and sexual abuse of women in France, where 94% of reported rape cases are dropped without any action. “From Gisèle Pelicot’s point of view, there is no sentence that will give her back what she has lost,” Babonneau said. “All Gisèle Pelicot wanted is to have the accused convicted for what they did to her. As for the personal sentences, she respects the decision of the court and finds no solace in them.”
b1_text:
He told us that she will be there. Maybe she will not be there every day. But she said she will go.

She is now a famous feminist around the world. This is because she wanted her trial to be public. She wanted everyone to see the videos of what happened to her. She wanted the shame to be on the abusers, not on her.

The trial made people in France think a lot. People want to change the laws about rape in France. They want to add the idea of "consent" to the laws. "Consent" means saying yes to something. This idea is not in the French laws now.

The trial also showed how people in France think about rape and abuse of women. Many rape cases in France are stopped. About 94 out of 100 reported rape cases are stopped without anything happening.

Babonneau said that Gisèle Pelicot will never get back what she lost. No punishment can do that. Gisèle Pelicot just wanted the people who hurt her to be found guilty. She respects the court's decision about the punishments. But the punishments do not make her feel better.

text: Work has begun to conserve and digitise one of the oldest paper documents still in existence on the island of Ireland. The ecclesiastical register, which dates back to the medieval period, is about 650 years old. It belonged to the former archbishop of Armagh Milo Sweteman. Its delicate pages are being repaired by experts at the Public Records Office of Northern Ireland (Proni) as part of an initiative to rejuvenate and preserve some of the island of Ireland’s most important historical texts. Ecclesiastical registers contain copies or drafts of documents created by the archbishops’ administration work, including legal papers, official letters, correspondence, receipts and wills. The register belonging to Sweteman dates to his time in the senior clerical role from 1361 to 1380. Conservation work on the register of archbishop John Swayne, dated from 1418 to 1438, has already been completed and a digitised copy, along with a translated summary, are now available online. The conservation work on the Swayne books involved carefully detaching bindings dating from the 17th century, gently washing all the paper folios and then consolidating each piece of paper with a weak gelatine solution. Tears and losses in the paper were infilled with Japanese kozo paper before the books were rebound using 17th-century binding material. The work now under way on the Sweteman register involves the need to repair damage that resulted from previous conservation efforts dating back to the start of the 20th century when tracing paper was placed on the pages in an attempt to preserve them. The tracing paper was acidic and actually accelerated the corrosion of the ink and paper. It is now being removed using a specialist gel before being subjected to a low-pressure washing process. The same kozo paper and wheat starch paste repairs used for Swayne’s register are then being undertaken. Similar work is being carried out on a third register, dated between 1400 and 1418, that belonged to former archbishop Nicholas Fleming. Sarah Graham, head of conservation at Proni, explained that paper was extremely rare on the island of Ireland when the registers were compiled.
b1_text:
Work has started on an old paper document. This document is very old. It is one of the oldest paper documents in Ireland.

The document is about 650 years old. It is from the Middle Ages. It was owned by Milo Sweteman. He was an archbishop in Armagh.

The pages of the document are very delicate. Experts are fixing them. They work at the Public Records Office of Northern Ireland (Proni). They are helping to save important old documents from Ireland.

These documents are called ecclesiastical registers. They have copies of papers from the archbishop. These papers include legal papers and letters. They also include receipts and wills.

Sweteman's register is from when he was archbishop. He was the archbishop from 1361 to 1380.

The experts already fixed another register. This register belonged to archbishop John Swayne. It is from 1418 to 1438. You can now see it online. There is also a simple explanation of it.

To fix Swayne's register, they took it apart. They cleaned each page with water. Then, they put a special liquid on the paper. This made the paper stronger. They fixed tears with special paper from Japan. Then, they put the book back together with old covers.

Now, they are working on Sweteman's register. They need to fix damage from before. People tried to save it a long time ago. They put thin paper on the pages. But this thin paper was bad for the document. It made the ink and paper get worse.

The experts are taking off the thin paper. They are using a special gel. Then, they will wash the pages gently. They will use the same Japanese paper and glue to fix it like they did for Swayne's register.

They are also working on a third register. This register belonged to archbishop Nicholas Fleming. It is from 1400 to 1418.

Sarah Graham works at Proni. She said that paper was rare in Ireland when these registers were made.

text: It was a period that just predated the invention of the printing press when parchment from animal skins was still the preferred writing material. “Paper that pre-dates 1450 is particularly rare, it didn’t occur in Ireland for a couple of centuries after the register of Milo Sweteman or the register of John Swayne were completed,” said Graham. “We’ve done some research into the watermarks and know that the paper came from Italy and from Spain.” Graham said it was likely the archbishops imported the paper to Ireland during their travels around Europe. The Virtual Record Treasury of Ireland is an effort to partially recreate the rich historical archive that was destroyed when the Public Record Office of Ireland in Dublin was set alight in June 1922 in the beginning of the Irish civil war. Graham emphasised the importance of preserving the centuries-old documents that do still exist. “The work that we do in conservation more broadly is really important to stabilise the collections so that they’re available to the public now, but they’re also available for generations to come, so that future generations are able to understand where they come from, what their history is, and the primary source of material is here and available to them,” she said.
b1_text:
Here is the rewritten text at a CEFR B1 level:

A long time ago, before people had printing presses, they wrote on animal skin. This animal skin was called parchment. Paper from before 1450 is very hard to find.

Graham said that paper like this did not come to Ireland for a long time. It came after two books were made. These books were called the register of Milo Sweteman and the register of John Swayne.

"We looked at the marks on the paper," said Graham. "We learned that the paper came from Italy and Spain."

Graham thinks that the archbishops brought the paper to Ireland. They probably got it when they traveled around Europe.

The Virtual Record Treasury of Ireland is trying to make a copy of old records. These records were lost when a building in Dublin burned down. This building was called the Public Record Office of Ireland. It burned in June 1922, at the start of the Irish civil war.

Graham said it is important to keep the old papers that we still have.

"We need to take care of these old papers," she said. "This will help people today see them. It will also help people in the future. They can learn about their history. They can see the old papers themselves."

text: South Korea’s intelligence agency has reported that a North Korean soldier believed to have been the first to be captured while supporting Russia’s war in Ukraine has died after being taken alive by Ukrainian forces. Seoul’s spy agency earlier on Friday confirmed Ukrainian reports that an injured North Korean soldier had been captured by Ukrainian forces, in what was likely to have been the first capture of its kind since Pyongyang sent combat forces to bolster Russian forces in the war. The South Korean national intelligence service said in a statement: “Through real-time information sharing with an allied country’s intelligence agency, it has been confirmed that one injured North Korean soldier has been captured.” The agency later said the captured soldier had died from his injuries. A photo of the soldier, who looked gaunt and appeared to have been injured, circulated on the Telegram messaging app, South Korea’s Yonhap news agency said. In his nightly video address on Friday, Volodymyr Zelenskyy said North Korean troops fighting in Russia’s Kursk region are suffering heavy losses and being left unprotected by Moscow’s forces. Ukraine’s president said Russian troops were doing everything to ensure that North Korean soldiers were not taken prisoner by Kyiv. He said some North Korean soldiers had been captured by Ukrainian forces, but were hurt so badly they could not be saved. Earlier the Ukrainian outlet Militarnyi reported that special forces had captured the soldier in the Kursk region, where Ukraine has seized and held some territory. The outlet did not say when the capture took place, and there has been no confirmation from officials in Ukraine or North Korea, where the state media have not referred to the deployment of the country’s troops. Militarnyi said that if it was confirmed, the soldier would be the first North Korean combatant to have been taken by Ukrainian forces. As many as 11,000 soldiers from North Korea have been deployed to help Russia, months after Kim Jong-un and Vladimir Putin signed a mutual defence pact that committed each country to come to the other’s aid if attacked. While the North could gain valuable battlefield experience, its poorly trained soldiers, fighting in unfamiliar territory, have quickly been exposed to the dangers of combat.
b1_text:
Here's the rewritten text at CEFR B1 level:

South Korea has an intelligence agency. This agency said a North Korean soldier has died. This soldier was fighting in Ukraine. He was captured by Ukrainian soldiers.

The South Korean agency said this on Friday. They knew this from reports from Ukraine. The North Korean soldier was hurt. Then, Ukrainian soldiers captured him. This may be the first time this has happened. North Korea sent soldiers to help Russia in the war.

The South Korean agency said they got information from another country's intelligence agency. They learned that a North Korean soldier was hurt and captured. Later, the agency said the soldier died from his injuries.

A picture of the soldier was shared online. He looked thin and hurt. This was reported by Yonhap, a news agency in South Korea.

Volodymyr Zelenskyy is the president of Ukraine. He spoke in a video. He said North Korean soldiers are fighting in the Kursk region of Russia. They are losing many soldiers. Russia is not protecting them well.

The Ukrainian president said Russian soldiers do not want North Korean soldiers to be captured. Some North Korean soldiers were captured, but they were very badly hurt. They could not be saved.

The Ukrainian website Militarnyi said special forces captured the soldier. This happened in the Kursk region. Ukraine has taken some land there. The website did not say when the soldier was captured.

No one in Ukraine or North Korea has said this is true. North Korean news has not talked about sending soldiers. Militarnyi said if this is true, the soldier is the first North Korean soldier captured in the war.

About 11,000 soldiers from North Korea are helping Russia. Kim Jong-un and Vladimir Putin made an agreement. They said they would help each other if attacked. This was months ago.

North Korean soldiers might get good experience fighting. But they are not well trained. They are fighting in a place they do not know. This is dangerous for them.

text: Ukraine’s military intelligence agency, known as the GUR, said on Thursday that North Korean troops were suffering heavy losses in the fighting in Kursk and facing logistical difficulties as a result of Ukrainian attacks. The GUR said Ukrainian strikes near Novoivanovka had inflicted heavy casualties on North Korean units and that North Korean troops also faced supply issues, including shortages of drinking water. This week Zelenskyy claimed that more than 3,000 North Korean troops had been killed or wounded in the Kursk region. It was the first significant estimate by Ukraine of North Korean casualties. On Friday a White House spokesperson said 1,000 North Korean troops had been killed or wounded in Kursk in the past week alone. “It is clear that Russian and North Korean military leaders are treating these troops as expendable and ordering them on hopeless assaults against Ukrainian defences,” John Kirby said. He described the North Korean troops’ offensive as “massed, dismounted assaults” and said Joe Biden was likely to approve another security assistance package for Ukraine in coming days. The deployment of North Korean soldiers marked a dramatic escalation in the war, which began almost three years ago, as the Kremlin turned to its ally to boost its forces. It was also seen as an attempt by Putin to broaden the conflict through the direct involvement in fighting of a third country. Slovakia, meanwhile, confirmed on Friday that it would host peace talks between Moscow and Kyiv, despite Ukraine’s accusation that it is playing into the hands of Putin. On Thursday the Russian president said it was “acceptable” for the country to become a “platform” for dialogue over the conflict, which the US president-elect, Donald Trump, has said he could end after he takes office in January. That prospect has raised concerns in Kyiv that a settlement could be imposed on terms favourable to Moscow, as Ukraine struggles on the battlefield.
b1_text:
Here is the text rewritten to CEFR B1 level:

Ukraine has a military spy group. It is called GUR. The GUR said on Thursday that North Korean soldiers are dying a lot in Kursk. They also have problems getting supplies. This is because Ukraine is attacking them.

The GUR said Ukraine attacked near Novoivanovka. Many North Korean soldiers died or were hurt. North Korean soldiers also do not have enough water and other things.

This week, Zelenskyy said that over 3,000 North Korean soldiers have died or were hurt in Kursk. This is the first time Ukraine has said how many North Korean soldiers have died.

On Friday, a person from the White House said that 1,000 North Korean soldiers died or were hurt in Kursk this week.

John Kirby said that Russia and North Korea do not care about these soldiers. They are sending them to attack, but they cannot win against Ukraine.

He said the North Korean soldiers are attacking in big groups, but they are not using vehicles. Joe Biden may send more help to Ukraine soon.

North Korea sending soldiers is a big change in the war. The war started almost three years ago. Russia asked North Korea to help because they need more soldiers.

People think Putin wants to make the war bigger. He wants another country to fight in the war too.

Slovakia said on Friday that they will have peace talks between Russia and Ukraine. But Ukraine thinks Slovakia is helping Putin.

On Thursday, the Russian president said that Slovakia can be a place to talk about the war. Donald Trump will become the US president in January. He said he can end the war.

This makes Ukraine worried. They think Russia might get a good deal, but it will be bad for Ukraine. Ukraine is having a hard time fighting.

text: At first, there seemed nothing to be afraid of. Joe Giardina, his wife, Evanna, and their 16-year-old son, Paul, were taking in the picture-perfect waters of Patong bay as they ate breakfast in their Phuket beachfront hotel on Boxing Day morning in 2004. “We were admiring the view and all of a sudden the water disappeared,” says Giardina, 67, speaking from his home in Rosanna, Victoria. The water level had dropped so quickly that fish were floundering on the exposed seabed. But rather than sensing any threat, curious onlookers made their way to the beach. “The locals thought, ‘This is fantastic.’ They were running around picking the fish up.” Now Giardina knows it’s a sign to flee to higher ground. About 550km to the south-west, a magnitude 9.15 earthquake had struck 30km below the Andaman Sea, triggering what would become the most devastating tsunami in history. Paul was one of 26 Australians among more than 230,000 people whose lives were lost across 14 countries – in some impact zones, the waves reached up to 3o metres above sea level. Twenty years on, Giardina’s memories of the disaster are as vivid as they were in its immediate aftermath. “It really feels like it was only yesterday,” he says of that initially deceptive morning. Within about half an hour the sea had returned to its normal level and settled, then it began to swirl, gently stirring up the sand below. Almost simultaneously, the nearby pier started to float away. A small amount of water – no more than 20cm – washed on to the road bordering the restaurant. “It didn’t look dangerous – we said, ‘We’re going to get wet,’” Giardina remembers. But when a car was washed towards the hotel, he began to run, leading Paul by the hand and then attempting to protect his son by holding him against a pillar inside the hotel. Seconds later, a waist-high wall of water hit them from behind, throwing them over an internal wall and ripping Giardina’s clothes from his body.
b1_text:
Joe Giardina, his wife Evanna, and their son Paul were on holiday. Paul was 16 years old. They were in Phuket, in Thailand. It was December 26, 2004. They were eating breakfast at their hotel. The hotel was on the beach in Patong bay.

Everything seemed fine. The sea looked beautiful. Then, something strange happened. Joe said, "We were looking at the view. Suddenly, the water went away." The water went down very fast. Fish were left on the sand. People were surprised. They went to the beach to look.

Joe said, "The people who lived there thought it was good. They were picking up the fish." Now Joe knows this was a warning. He knows it meant they should go to higher ground.

Far away, about 550 km, there was a big earthquake. It was under the sea. The earthquake was very strong. It caused a tsunami. A tsunami is a very big wave. This tsunami was the worst one ever.

Paul died in the tsunami. He was one of 26 Australians who died. More than 230,000 people died in 14 countries. The waves were very high in some places, up to 30 meters.

Joe remembers the tsunami very well. It has been 20 years, but he still remembers it clearly. He said, "It feels like it was yesterday."

That morning, the sea looked normal again after the water went away. Then the water started to move around. It moved the sand. Then, the pier near them started to float away. A little water came onto the road. It was not very high. It was about 20 cm. Joe said, "It did not look dangerous. We thought we would just get wet."

But then, a car was pushed by the water towards the hotel. Joe knew they had to run. He took Paul's hand and ran. They went inside the hotel. Joe tried to keep Paul safe near a pillar. Then, a big wave of water hit them. It was very strong. It threw them over a wall. The water even pulled Joe's clothes off.

text: Cars and tables slammed into the building as everything in the path of the 800km/h wave was lifted and flung high. Something hit Giardina on the back of the head and he went under, losing hold of Paul. Giardina found himself pushed horizontally against the outer corner of the hotel when a large object – a car, a fridge, he’ll never know – pinned his left arm to the wall. “I’m trying with my right hand to get out, get around the corner, to push away whatever was holding me. And I just couldn’t get there. I was underwater and I held my breath for as long as I could. The last thing I recall is just opening my mouth and that was it. The lights went off.” Today, he still finds consolation in the thought that Paul, whose body was found in a makeshift morgue by Joe’s brothers-in-law three days later, might have experienced something similar. “I can only hope – and it’s terrible – but I can only hope that Paul went through the same experience,” he says. “There was no suffering.” The Giardinas had weighed up whether to visit Thailand or Bali for Paul’s first overseas trip. Paul had Down’s syndrome and, while physically high-functioning, was unable to care for himself. Phuket seemed a safer option two years after Bali’s terrorist attacks and the family – Paul’s sister, two years his senior, stayed in Australia – chose to celebrate Christmas at Patong’s Seaview hotel, where Paul played ball in the swimming pool and was photographed smiling with Santa. Joe and Evanna called their affectionate son the “love machine”. “Twice in his short life, he had open heart surgery. The second time, he’d had a valve replaced in his heart, and when he’s woken up from the surgery, what was his first comment? It wasn’t tears and crying and screaming, it was ‘What happened?’ There wouldn’t be too many of us behaving that way,” Joe Giardina says, laughing. Giardina was found inside the hotel, lying prone and headfirst down a flight of steps on the third storey.
b1_text:
The very fast wave was like a strong wind. It was going 800 kilometers per hour. It picked up cars and tables. It threw them into the building.

Something hit Giardina on his head. He fell down and lost his grip on Paul.

Giardina was pushed against the hotel wall. A big thing pinned his arm. It could have been a car or a fridge. He did not know.

He tried to move away with his other hand. He could not. He was underwater. He held his breath.

He opened his mouth. Then he lost consciousness. Everything went dark.

Later, Paul's body was found. Joe's family found him after three days.

Giardina hopes Paul did not suffer. He hopes Paul had a similar experience. He thinks there was no pain for Paul.

The Giardinas wanted to take Paul on a trip. They thought about Thailand or Bali. Paul had Down's syndrome. He needed help to take care of himself.

They chose Phuket because it seemed safer. It was two years after the Bali attacks.

The family stayed at the Seaview hotel. Paul played with a ball in the pool. He took a picture with Santa. His sister stayed in Australia.

Joe and Evanna loved their son very much. They called him the "love machine."

Paul had two heart surgeries. After the second surgery, he woke up. He did not cry. He asked, "What happened?" Joe Giardina laughed when he remembered this.

Giardina was found inside the hotel. He was lying on the stairs. His head was down. He was on the third floor.

text: His position saved his life: water drained out of his body. Initially deemed unlikely to survive, he was eventually taken to Bangkok hospital in Phuket, where the pain from his extensive injuries was numbed by the fear that he had lost Paul and Evanna. His wife was found unhurt and later reunited with him – she had ridden the wave to the hotel, grabbed hold of a balcony and miraculously avoided being sucked back out to sea. When Giardina was medevaced to Melbourne, the doctors’ first job was to flush the sand out of his lungs. “The one thing that it has taught me is how quickly it can all come to an end. You appreciate every day when you go through something like that,” he says, describing the speed at which the morning went from one of tropical calm to earth-shattering calamity. He and Evanna are grateful to have found Paul’s body among Thailand’s 5,400 victims, “because if we hadn’t, I know that there would be a sense of ‘He could be out there still’. And where do you start? We would have been walking the streets looking for him. And that would have been …” He pauses. “How do you cope with that?” It’s not accidental that when visitors to the Indian Ocean Tsunami Memorial take in the wave-shaped sculpture on the shore of Lake Burley Griffin in Canberra, they are also facing the water. Giardina instigated the memorial and requested that its aspect include water. Its unveiling in December 2015 was the first time Joe and Evanna had met all 25 of the other Australian victims’ families, after a 10-year process involving three governments. It’s given them a place where they can remember Paul, and this 26 December they plan to be there again, with their son in spirit. But part of Paul will always remain in Phuket. Joe and Evanna returned to Patong in October 2005 and again on the first anniversary of the disaster, and Joe has visited Thailand many times since, partly so that the tsunami does not dictate how he lives. “It’s part of the healing. I feel like part of Paul is there. If I didn’t go back, the tsunami would win.
b1_text:
He was in a certain place, and this helped him stay alive. The water went out of his body. At first, people did not think he would live. But he went to a hospital in Phuket, Thailand. The hospital was in Bangkok. He was in a lot of pain because he had many injuries. But he was also worried about Paul and Evanna. He thought they might be dead.

His wife, Evanna, was okay. She was not hurt. She was with him again later. She was on the wave, but she got to the hotel. She held onto a balcony. She was lucky and did not go back into the sea.

Joe was taken to Melbourne by plane to get medical help. Doctors cleaned the sand out of his lungs. Joe said that this event showed him how fast things can change. He said he is thankful for every day because of what happened. That morning, it was calm and nice. Then, very quickly, everything became terrible.

Joe and Evanna are happy that they found Paul's body. Many people died in Thailand, about 5,400. They are happy they found Paul because if they had not, they would think he might still be alive. They would not know where to look for him. They would be looking for him on the streets. Joe said it would be very hard to deal with that.

There is a special place in Canberra to remember the tsunami. It is called the Indian Ocean Tsunami Memorial. It has a statue that looks like a wave. The statue faces the water. Joe made this memorial happen. He wanted it to face the water.

The memorial opened in December 2015. It was the first time Joe and Evanna met the families of the other Australians who died. There were 25 other families. It took 10 years to build the memorial. Three different groups of people in the government helped.

The memorial is a place where they can remember Paul. They will go there on December 26th. They will remember Paul.

But part of Paul will always be in Phuket. Joe and Evanna went back to Patong in October 2005. They also went back on the first year that they remember the tsunami. Joe has gone to Thailand many times since then. He goes so the tsunami does not control his life. He says it helps him feel better. He feels like part of Paul is there. If he did not go back, the tsunami would win.

text: It’s taken my son’s life, and now we’re not going to go to the beach any more because of the tsunami? I didn’t want that either. It’s a rare event, but when it happens, it causes damage, and we’ve just got to accept it.” Now he can speak about the tsunami without crying – but it is a work in progress. “As humans, we learn to cope with tragedies. You don’t forget the pain, but you learn to live with the pain. We had 16 beautiful years with Paul, but it’s the journey of life. Life is what it is and you’ve just got to accept it. And we’re grateful we were able to spend 16 years with him.”
b1_text:
My son died. It was because of the tsunami. Now, we will not go to the beach again. I don't want this.

Tsunamis don't happen often. But when they do, they make a lot of damage. We have to accept it.

Now I can talk about the tsunami. I don't cry now. But it is still hard.

People can learn to deal with sad things. We don't forget the pain. But we can learn to live with it.

We had Paul for 16 good years. This is just how life is. You need to accept life.

We are happy we had 16 years with him.

text: The United Nations chief has denounced the “escalation” in hostilities between Yemen’s Houthi rebels and Israel, calling IDF strikes on targets including at the airport in Sana’a “especially alarming” after it came under attack while the head of the World Health Organization was about to board a plane. Israel struck multiple targets linked to the Iran-aligned Houthi movement in Yemen on Thursday, including the international airport in the capital, Sana’a. Houthi media said at least six people were killed. A spokesperson for UN secretary general, António Guterres, said in a statement: “The secretary general condemns the escalation between Yemen and Israel. Israeli airstrikes today on Sana’a international airport, the Red Sea ports and power stations in Yemen are especially alarming … “Today’s airstrikes follow around a year of escalatory actions by the Houthis in the Red Sea and the region that threaten civilians, regional stability and freedom of maritime navigation.” The head of the World Health Organization (WHO), Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said in a social media post on Thursday that he was about to board a plane at the airport when it came under aerial attack. A crew member on the plane was injured, he said, and at least two people were reported killed at the airport. “The air traffic control tower, the departure lounge – just a few meters from where we were – and the runway were damaged. We will need to wait for the damage to the airport to be repaired before we can leave. My UN and @WHO colleagues and I are safe. Our heartfelt condolences to the families whose loved ones lost their lives in the attack.” Tedros said he had been in Yemen to negotiate the release of UN staff detained by the Houthis and assess the humanitarian situation. The Israeli military did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Agence France-Presse on whether they were aware of Tedros’ presence at the time. Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said on Thursday afternoon that Israel’s air force attacked Houthi targets on the coastline and in Sanaa, adding: “We are determined to cut off this terrorist arm of Iran’s evil axis.
b1_text:
The leader of the United Nations is worried. The fighting between the Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israel is getting worse. This is called an "escalation."

Israel attacked some places in Yemen. These places included the airport in Sana'a. Sana'a is the capital city of Yemen. The UN leader said these attacks are very worrying.

The attacks happened when the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) was at the airport. He was going to get on a plane.

Israel attacked the Houthi group in Yemen on Thursday. The Houthi group is helped by Iran. The airport in Sana'a was one of the places attacked.

Houthi news said that at least six people died.

A spokesperson for the UN leader, António Guterres, said something about this. He said that the UN leader is against the fighting getting worse. He said the attacks on the airport, the ports on the Red Sea, and power stations are very worrying.

The spokesperson also said that the Houthi group has been doing things that make the situation worse for about a year. These actions put people in danger. They also cause problems for the area and for ships that need to travel safely.

The head of the WHO is Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus. He said he was at the airport when it was attacked. He wrote about it on social media.

He said a person who worked on the plane was hurt. He also said that at least two people died at the airport.

He said the control tower, the waiting area, and the runway were damaged. These places were near where he was. He said they must wait for the airport to be fixed before they can leave. He and his UN and WHO friends are safe. He feels sad for the families who lost people in the attack.

Tedros said he was in Yemen to talk about getting UN workers released. The Houthi group was keeping them. He also wanted to see how people in Yemen are doing.

The Israeli military did not say if they knew Tedros was at the airport when they attacked.

The leader of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, said something on Thursday. He said Israel's air force attacked Houthi places on the coast and in Sanaa. He said they want to stop the Houthi group because they are terrorists and work with Iran.

text: We will persist in this until we complete the task.” Netanyahu said in an interview with Channel 14 that Israel was only at the beginning of its campaign against the Houthis. “We are just getting started with them,” he said. Houthis have repeatedly fired drones and missiles towards Israel in what they describe as acts of solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza. The Israeli military said that in addition to striking the airport, it also hit military infrastructure at the ports of Hodeidah, Salif and Ras Kanatib on Yemen’s west coast. It also attacked the country’s Hezyaz and Ras Kanatib power stations. The Houthi-controlled Saba news agency said that three people were killed in the strikes on the airport and three were killed in Hodeidah, while 40 others were wounded in the attacks. Later on Thursday, the Houthis said they were ready to respond quickly to the attack and meet “escalation with escalation”, Houthi-run Al Masirah TV reported. The Houthi transport minister told Saba that both the airport and Hodeidah port would resume normal operations from Friday. More than a year of Houthi attacks has disrupted international shipping routes, forcing firms to re-route to longer and more expensive journeys that have in turn stoked fears over global inflation. The UN security council is due to meet on Monday over the Houthi attacks on Israel, Israel’s UN ambassador Danny Danon said on Wednesday. On Saturday, Israel’s military failed to intercept a missile from Yemen that fell in the Tel Aviv-Jaffa area, injuring 14 people. With Reuters and Agence France-Presse
b1_text:
Here is the text rewritten for CEFR level B1:

Netanyahu said they will keep going. They will keep going until the task is done. He said this in an interview. He was talking to Channel 14. He said Israel is just starting its fight against the Houthis.

He said, "We are just getting started with them."

The Houthis have fired drones and missiles at Israel many times. They say they are helping the Palestinians in Gaza.

The Israeli army said they attacked the airport. They also attacked military buildings at the ports. These ports are Hodeidah, Salif, and Ras Kanatib. They are on the west coast of Yemen. They also attacked power stations in Hezyaz and Ras Kanatib.

The Saba news agency is controlled by the Houthis. They said three people died at the airport. Three people died in Hodeidah. Forty other people were hurt in the attacks.

Later, the Houthis said they are ready to fight back quickly. They said they will make the fight bigger. They told this to Al Masirah TV, which they control.

The Houthi transport minister spoke to Saba. He said the airport and Hodeidah port will open again on Friday.

The Houthis have attacked ships for over a year. This has made problems for ships around the world. The ships have to go a longer way. This costs more money. People are worried that things will cost more in the shops because of this.

The UN Security Council will meet on Monday. They will talk about the Houthi attacks on Israel. Danny Danon, Israel's UN ambassador, said this on Wednesday.

On Saturday, Israel's army did not stop a missile from Yemen. The missile fell in Tel Aviv-Jaffa. Fourteen people were hurt.

This information is from Reuters and Agence France-Presse.

text: Paul Volcker, who has died aged 92, was the most eminent financial statesman of his generation, the sworn enemy of the abuse of finance in any of its manifestations. That could be indulging inflation as the financial outcome of governments and society living beyond their means, or investment banks deluding themselves they had uncovered the alchemy of risk-free lending through the issuance of ever more complex financial derivatives. His twin mantras were that finance should be the servant not the master of economy and society. And that good government is an indispensable component of a good society, in particular keeping the temptations of clever-clever finance at bay. Sound money and good government went hand in hand. He practised what he preached, seizing the opportunity to embody his beliefs when the moment arrived. Standing over 6ft 7in, and a lover of over-sized cigars and fly-fishing, he represented the best of New England liberalism – genial, good humoured and steely. From August 1979 to August 1987 he was chairman of the US Federal Reserve, the US’s central bank, appointed by Democrat President Jimmy Carter and and reappointed by Republican President Ronald Reagan. In the early part of that period he crushed inflation out of the US economy. Just 18 months after he was appointed he had the courage to raise interest rates to 20% – a rate never seen before – prompting mass protests as the US economy plunged into recession. But he held firm and succeeded, inflation peaking at 14.8% before falling back to 3% by 1983. The foundations had been laid for sustained economic recovery and in the process warranting the principle that central bank independence is a crucial precondition for robust monetary policy. It was one of the defining moments in US monetary policy history, winning him plaudits not only for his resilience in the face of near universal criticism but also from the small but fast growing influential band of free market, “monetarist” economists who believed that control of the money supply using high interest rates was the sole means to curb inflation – not any kind of government interference into the market processes for setting wages and prices. Volcker temporarily was their hero. But they misjudged the man.
b1_text:
Paul Volcker died. He was 92 years old. He was a very important person in the world of money. He did not like it when money was used in the wrong way.

He thought it was wrong when governments spent too much money. This can cause prices to go up, which is called inflation. He also did not like it when banks tried to make money by taking big risks.

He believed that money should help people and the economy. Money should not be in control. He also thought that good government was important. A good government should stop people from being too clever with money. He believed that good money and good government should work together.

He did what he believed was right. He was a tall man who liked big cigars and fishing. He was a kind and strong person.

From 1979 to 1987, he was in charge of the US Federal Reserve. This is the central bank of the United States. President Jimmy Carter and President Ronald Reagan chose him for this job.

At that time, prices were going up very fast in the US. It was a big problem. Volcker stopped this inflation.

He raised interest rates very high. This made it more expensive to borrow money. Some people did not like this. The economy got worse for a short time.

But Volcker did not change his mind. He kept the interest rates high. Finally, the prices stopped going up so fast. Inflation went down from almost 15% to 3%.

This helped the economy to get better. It also showed that central banks need to be independent. This means they should not be controlled by the government. This is important for making good decisions about money.

It was a very important time for money in the US. People praised Volcker for being strong. Some economists also liked him. These economists thought that high interest rates were the best way to stop inflation. They did not want the government to control prices and wages. For a while, Volcker was their hero. But they were wrong about him.

text: Volcker never bought the proposition that the market was magical or that there could be a systematic relationship between the growth of the money supply and inflation. Rather he was intuitively suspicious of the short term and predatory instincts of most financial market participants, which lead to volatile and unpredictable market movements, and intuitively suspicious of the mania for dismantling the New Deal rules and regulations that restrained their worst types of behaviours that “free market“ economists said were inhibiting the efficiency of the US financial system. His willingness to be austere in raising interest rates so high was because he knew dear money worked reliably in squeezing inflation – not because he was an advocate of a hyper-free-market economy. He would be equally austere in resisting the siren calls to deregulate finance in the name of freeing up the market. It would come to no good. Nor did it. Volcker was a critic of successive rounds of financial deregulation after he left office, saying that the only useful financial innovation he had encountered was the invention of the ATM – cash dispensing machines. Even before the 2008-09 financial crisis he was warning that the invention of mortgage backed securities and credit default swaps were inherently unstable, in effect transferring risk to the Federal Reserve, which would be compelled to underwrite the financial system if the markets ever lost confidence in them. So it proved as the financial crisis broke for precisely the reasons about which he had warned – unlike his successor Alan Greenspan, who had enthusiastically and uncritically embraced financial deregulation. President Obama appointed him head of the president’s economic advisory board in 2009 in the midst of the crisis. There he argued that the emergence of banks that were too big to fail, so forcing central bank rescues, was morally and economically insupportable and they should be broken up. If that was politically impossible then at least commercial banks who took deposits from the ordinary public should be banned from trading in high-risk financial derivatives on their own account – the so-called Volcker rule. Obama adopted the proposal and it became section 619 of the 2010 Dodd Frank Wall Street Reform Act; banks cannot own, invest in or sponsor hedge funds, private equity funds or other trading operations for their own use.
b1_text:
Paul Volcker did not think the market was perfect. He did not think that more money always meant more inflation. He did not trust people in the financial market. He thought they were often greedy and made the market go up and down quickly.

Volcker did not like the idea of getting rid of rules from the New Deal. These rules controlled bad actions in the market. Some economists thought these rules stopped the market from working well.

Volcker raised interest rates very high. He knew this would stop inflation. He did not want a completely free market. He also did not want to remove rules about money. He thought it was a bad idea. And he was right.

After Volcker left his job, he said that getting rid of financial rules was bad. He said the only good new thing in finance was the ATM.

Before 2008, Volcker warned about new types of investments. These were things like mortgage-backed securities. He said they were not safe. He thought they gave risk to the Federal Reserve bank. The Federal Reserve would have to help if people lost trust in these investments.

This happened in the 2008 financial crisis. The crisis happened because of the things Volcker had warned about. Alan Greenspan, who came after Volcker, had liked the idea of getting rid of financial rules.

In 2009, President Obama asked Volcker to help with the crisis. Volcker said that some banks were too big. If they failed, the government would have to save them. He said this was not fair. He thought these banks should be made smaller.

If that was not possible, Volcker said that banks should not be allowed to trade risky things. These banks took money from normal people. This idea was called the "Volcker rule".

Obama liked this idea. It became a rule in 2010. Now, banks cannot own or invest in some risky funds for their own profit.

text: Volcker had once again made an indelible mark on the US financial system, and influenced British thinking in the legal obligation to ringfence commercial and investment bank operations. Born in Cape May, on the southern tip of New Jersey, Paul Jr was the son of Paul Volcker, a civil engineer, and his wife, Alma (nee Klippel); his grandparents were all German immigrants. He grew up in the conventional world of 1930s and 40s America – going to high school, attending the local Lutheran church, but already showing an interest in public affairs and a precocious intelligence . He gained a degree in history, economics and political science at Princeton University (1949), and went on to do a master’s in political economy and government at Harvard, and to study at the London school of Economics. In 1952 he joined the New York Federal Reserve as an economist. A career alternating between Wall Street and the US Treasury in ever more responsible jobs then followed before fatefully he caught the eye of President Carter in 1979. He was a convinced believer in international collaboration, helping to fashion the Plaza accords in 1986 when Germany and Japan agreed to allow their currencies to appreciate, so limiting their trade imbalances with the US. This vital adjustment, he knew, would not come from market forces spontaneously but from intergovernmental collaboration. He was a founder of the Trilateral Commission, to foster relations between Japan, western Europe and north America, and regular attender at the Bilderberg meetings of leaders and experts from Europe and north America, believing that the key international players had to understand each other better. Towards the end of his life this believer in the power, capacity and importance of good government became increasingly concerned about the collapse of trust in government, founding the Volcker Alliance to advance the understanding of – and education for – careers in public service. In 1954 he married Barbara Bahnson; she died in 1998. In 2010 he married Anke Dening, and she survives him, along with James and Janice, the children of his first marriage. • Paul Adolph Volcker, central banker and economist, born 5 September 1927; died 8 December 2019
b1_text:
Paul Volcker changed the US financial system. He also affected how banks work in Britain.

Paul Volcker was born in Cape May, New Jersey. His father was Paul Volcker, a builder. His mother was Alma. His grandparents came from Germany.

He grew up in America in the 1930s and 1940s. He went to high school and church. He was interested in what was happening in the world. He was very smart.

He studied history, economics, and politics at Princeton University. He got a degree in 1949. Then, he studied more at Harvard and in London.

In 1952, he started working as an economist at the New York Federal Reserve.

He worked on Wall Street and for the US government. He had more and more important jobs. In 1979, President Carter noticed him.

He believed countries should work together. In 1986, he helped create the Plaza Accords. Germany and Japan agreed to make their money worth more. This helped with trade problems with the US. He knew this needed countries to work together. It would not happen by itself.

He started the Trilateral Commission. This group helped Japan, Europe, and North America work together. He also went to Bilderberg meetings. These meetings were for leaders and experts from Europe and North America. He thought important people from different countries needed to understand each other.

Later in his life, he worried that people did not trust the government. He started the Volcker Alliance. This group helped people learn about working for the government.

He married Barbara Bahnson in 1954. She died in 1998. In 2010, he married Anke Dening. She is still alive. He had two children, James and Janice, from his first marriage.

Paul Adolph Volcker was a central banker and economist. He was born on September 5, 1927. He died on December 8, 2019.

text: High street sales slumped in November in the weakest period for consumer spending for more than a year, as shoppers reined in their spending in the run-up to Christmas. The Office for National Statistics said retail sales across Britain fell by 0.6% when compared with the previous month, with only household goods stores reporting growth. In a sign of the stress facing retailers, the quantity of goods bought dropped by 0.4% in the three months to November compared with the previous three months, the first decline since April 2018. Annual growth in sales also slowed to 1%, mainly because of a slump in spending in non-food stores. The latest figures from the high street and online suggest heavy discounting around Black Friday failed to tempt consumers to part with their cash in one of the worst periods for retailers in recent decades. Analysts said unsettled weather, political and economic uncertainty over Brexit and the snap election, and consumers leaving their shopping to the last minute in hope of bigger discounts, all had an impact last month. High street retailers are also struggling with rising wage bills and the cost of business rates, as well as tough competition as consumers switch to online shopping. Recognising the difficulties on the high street, the government said it was committed to a “fundamental review” of business rates and announced new measures to help independent retailers in the Queen’s speech on Thursday. The measures include a 50% discount on business rates for small to medium-sized high street properties including shops, pubs and restaurants with a rateable value of less than £51,000, up from a 33% discount at present. The discount is also being extended to cinemas and music venues. The plans are unlikely to do much to help troubled major retailers such as House of Fraser or Debenhams as retail chains are not eligible for the discount and neither are large department stores. November was the fourth month in a row without growth in retail spending – the longest stretch since the mid-90s. The ONS said Black Friday was not included in the figures, as the US-inspired day of shopping discounts fell late in the month, on 29 November. It said its seasonally adjusted estimates accounted for this shift in timing. However, analysts said the timing of Black Friday could have had an impact and probably distorted November’s spending figures. The ONS said Black Friday spending patterns would probably influence its December release, with only early promotions captured in the November estimates.
b1_text:
Shops on the high street sold less in November. This was the worst time for shopping in over a year. People did not spend much money before Christmas.

The Office for National Statistics said that shop sales in Britain went down by 0.6%. This is when compared to the month before. Only shops selling things for the house sold more.

Shops are having problems. People bought 0.4% fewer things in the three months before November. This is compared to the three months before that. This is the first time sales have gone down since April 2018.

The sales went up only 1% compared to last year. This is because people did not buy many things from non-food shops.

Shops in the high street and online had big sales for Black Friday. But people did not want to spend their money. It was a very bad time for shops.

Experts said that the weather was bad. Also, people were not sure about Brexit and the election. People waited to buy things, hoping for better sales. All these things made a difference last month.

Shops on the high street also have to pay more money to workers. The cost of business rates is also high. It is hard for them because more people are shopping online.

The government knows that shops on the high street are having problems. They said they will look at the business rates again. They also said they will help small shops. This was in the Queen's speech.

Small shops, pubs, and restaurants will pay 50% less in business rates. This is for shops that are not too big. Now, they pay 33% less. Cinemas and music places will also pay less.

But this will not help big shops like House of Fraser or Debenhams. Big shops cannot get this discount.

November was the fourth month in a row that shop sales did not go up. This is the longest time since the 90s.

The Office for National Statistics said that Black Friday is not in the numbers. Black Friday was at the end of November, on the 29th. They said that the numbers take this into account.

But experts said that Black Friday might have made a difference. It probably changed the numbers for November.

The Office for National Statistics said that Black Friday will probably change the numbers for December. Only the sales before Black Friday are in the November numbers.

text: Duncan Brewer, a retail partner at the consultancy Oliver Wyman, said political uncertainty had lifted since the election and unemployment remained low, in a positive signal for consumer spending. However, he warned that at least two high street shopping chains were likely to go bust next year and about 100,000 jobs were likely to be cut across the sector. He said: “The slump in retail sales over November goes to show that despite the momentous shopping holiday of Black Friday and Cyber Monday, discounting periods are not an effective way of getting people into the shops.”
b1_text:
Okay, here's the rewritten text at a CEFR B1 level:

Duncan Brewer works for a company called Oliver Wyman. He helps shops. He said things are better now because the election is finished. Also, not many people are out of work. This is good for shops because people can spend money.

But Duncan said something bad might happen. He thinks that two big shops will close next year. This means that about 100,000 people who work in shops might lose their jobs.

Duncan also talked about sales. He said that shops had bad sales in November. This is even though there was Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These are days when shops sell things for less money. Duncan thinks that selling things for less does not help shops get more customers.

text: No one has dug into the vaults of the Bank of England and pilfered a gold bar, but security breaches for a central bank in the 21st-century age of information do not come much worse than this. Hedge funds have managed to gain access to an audio feed of the governor’s press conferences, thereby securing for themselves an advantage of a few seconds over viewers of the slightly delayed TV broadcast. In modern frantic markets, seconds can matter. The misuse of the audio feed by an unnamed third-party supplier is “wholly unacceptable”, said the Bank after the report by the Times. The governor, Mark Carney, will be squirming with embarrassment. He arrived in 2013 on a mission to modernise the Bank’s operations and information security was top of the list. Now Threadneedle Street stands accused of gross naivety. The audio feed was designed as a back-up in case the TV system failed, but the potential for mischief should have been obvious. The Bank left a back door, if not wide open, then significantly ajar. The call for somebody’s resignation will be loud. No hedge fund or trader, it should be said, had advance knowledge of the Bank’s actual policy decisions, which are the main event on these stage-managed occasions. Interest rate decisions, for example, are announced to the world on the stroke of midday, and the full set of accompanying documents is published simultaneously. Journalists are allowed to read the contents in advance only if they are locked in the bowels of the Bank until midday in a secure room with no wifi or mobile phone signal. The security breach concerns only the press conferences, which start at 12.30pm. A consolation for the Bank, one could argue, is that Carney’s press conferences tend to be spectacularly dull. He’s in the business of explaining reports that are in the public domain by the time he speaks and he tends not to stray far from his mental script. For ordinary mortals, a five-second informational advantage might be useless. Even five minutes to wade through Carney’s sub-clauses might not yield nuggets to indicate if the pound should be moving up, down or sideways.
b1_text:
It is very hard to steal gold from the Bank of England. But something bad happened with the Bank's security. This happened in the 21st century, when information is very important.

Some hedge funds got secret access. They could listen to the audio of the governor's speeches before everyone else. The governor is the head of the Bank. The hedge funds could hear the audio a few seconds before people watching TV.

In today's markets, even a few seconds can be important. This gave the hedge funds an advantage. The Bank of England said that this was "not acceptable." This happened because of a third-party company. This company should not have done this.

The governor, Mark Carney, will be upset. He started working at the Bank in 2013. He wanted to make the Bank modern. He also wanted to improve security. Now, people think the Bank was careless.

The audio was meant to be a backup. It was for if the TV system did not work. But it was easy for people to misuse it. The Bank did not protect the audio well enough. People will want someone to lose their job because of this.

The hedge funds did not know the Bank's plans before they were announced. The important decisions are still secret until they are made public. For example, interest rates are announced at 12:00. All the documents are released at the same time.

Journalists can read the documents early. But they must stay in a secure room at the Bank until 12:00. They cannot use Wi-Fi or their phones. The security problem was only with the press conferences, which start at 12:30.

The Bank can feel a little better because the governor's speeches are often boring. He talks about reports that people can already read. He usually says what he has planned.

For most people, a few seconds of information is not helpful. Even a few minutes to read the governor's words might not help them know if the British pound will go up or down.

text: The trouble is, there is a breed of hedge funds that does not operate like ordinary mortals do. They’re pursuing fast action and even the possibility of morsels of information count in their world. Some even run artificial intelligence computer programmes to alight on specific words or phrases and then trade instantly, and perhaps only for a brief second, on what they learn. This type of hedge fund may also be interested in what Carney doesn’t say, as much as what he does, in response to a question. Such strategies seek only marginal gains, and success is clearly not guaranteed, but a central bank simply cannot give anybody any theoretical opportunity to get ahead of the market. The fallout from this affair will be fascinating. The Financial Conduct Authority will have to decide if the third-party supplier (which surely won’t remain unidentified for long) has merely breached its contract with the Bank or has committed market abuse, which is a serious regulatory matter. The market abuse question also applies to the hedge funds, though the FCA will face an obvious difficulty in proving that a trade was placed because of access to the audio feed rather than something unrelated. This could be groundbreaking territory. The judgment on the Bank of England, by contrast, is already clear. It looks amateurish.
b1_text:
Some hedge funds are different. They do not work like normal people. They want to act very fast. Even small pieces of information are important to them.

Some use computers with special programs. These programs look for certain words or phrases. Then, the computers trade very quickly, maybe for only one second. They trade based on what they find.

These hedge funds might also watch what someone *does not* say. For example, they might watch what Mr. Carney doesn't say when someone asks him a question. They want to gain a small advantage.

Winning is not certain for them. But a big bank like the central bank can't let anyone get ahead in the market. That is not allowed.

This situation will be interesting. The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) will have to decide what happened. Did the company that gave the information break the rules of their contract with the bank? Or did they do something illegal called "market abuse?" This is a serious problem.

The FCA will also look at the hedge funds. Did they trade because they heard the audio early? Or did they trade for another reason? It will be hard for the FCA to prove why they traded. This could be a new situation for the FCA.

However, we already know what we think about the Bank of England. They made a mistake. It looks like they were not professional.

text: Saturday was not so super for retailers last weekend, as numbers visiting high streets and shopping centres fell by nearly 8% compared with the previous year. With some retailers accepting online orders as late as Christmas Eve, shoppers now have many more choices about the way they shop and often hang on for last-minute bargains. More than a third (36%) of Brits have left gift-buying until the last few days before Christmas, according to Argos. It said 10% more men than women leave gift-buying until very late, with the most popular gift bought in its stores on Christmas Eve last year being an electric toothbrush. John Lewis expected novelty socks and gadgets such as airpods and smart speakers to be its most popular last-minute items. Monday was expected to be the busiest day for food retailers with Waitrose expecting to sell 214,000kg of sprouts in the final days before Christmas and 250% more quails eggs than usual. The lower turnout recorded by shopper monitoring firm Springboard on Saturday –traditionally one of the busiest shopping days of the year – came despite a flurry of discounts from retailers in an effort to tempt bargain hunters after a difficult trading year. Industry experts said the plethora of promotions on offer since November, and particularly over the Black Friday discount period at the end of November, meant many had spent their money early or were underwhelmed by further price cuts. Late last week Topshop and Miss Selfridge increased their discounts to up to 60%, from 40% and 50% respectively earlier in the week, while Jigsaw, Peacocks and House of Fraser increased their price cuts to 50%, matching Debenhams, Hobbs and Oasis, which had deepened their discounts. Marks & Spencer also added knitwear to its price-cutting pile, offering 40% off its key seasonal category, as well as a half-price on beauty gifts offer. The difficult trading is expected to bring further distress for retailers in early 2020 after numerous administrations and store closures this year. The number of retailers in financial distress in the final quarter of the year has risen 1.4% on the same period last year to 27,000, according to data from the corporate recovery firm Begbies Traynor. Fashion chains are among the worst affected, with the number in distress increasing by 21% in the past three years to 3,355.

Argos said that 36% of people in Britain buy gifts just before Christmas. This is more than one third of all people. Men are more likely to buy gifts late than women. Last year, the most popular gift at Argos on Christmas Eve was an electric toothbrush.

A company called Springboard checks how many people go to shops. They said that fewer people went shopping on Saturday. This was despite shops having sales. Shops wanted to get more people to buy things after a bad year.
