The law says that people in charge of pensions must give the money within six months when someone asks for it.

The court said no to Garner's request. This is bad for him. It looks like he may have to declare himself bankrupt. This means he may have no money.

Leicester city council has already asked the court to say he is bankrupt.

Garner had to pay the £14 million to the people who had pensions. Most of these people did not work for Norton. He did not pay while the court thought about his request to change the decision.

In August, a judge said that Garner probably could not pay the money. He said that Garner might have to declare himself bankrupt.

But now, the judge said that there was no reason to wait to pay the money.

Garner can ask the court to change another decision. This decision is about £180,000. This money is for 30 people. These people are part of a group of 228 people who had pensions. He did not give them their money when he should have.

Garner's lawyers said that he can ask the court about the £180,000. He also asked the court again to let him change the first decision.

Garner was in charge of the Norton pension funds. He used all the money from the pensions to invest in his own company. But Norton had problems and closed on January 29.

text: The ombudsman’s determination in the summer stated: “The trustee has acted dishonestly and in breach of his duty of no conflict, his duty not to profit and his duty to act with prudence.” The decision followed a Guardian and ITV News investigation in January that showed how 228 “ordinary working people” had had their entire pension pots invested into Norton shares after they had been duped by a fraudster. Garner received the retirement savings during 2012 and 2013, after a scam that resulted in a promoter, Simon Colfer, being convicted of fraud in 2018 for the way he had sold the scheme. Two further Garner associates involved in setting up the Norton pensions schemes, Andrew Meeson and Peter Bradley, were convicted of a separate tax fraud in 2013, when they reclaimed £5m of tax rebates from fictitious pension contributions. Court documents from that trial show that £990,000 of the fraud proceeds were loaned to Garner to acquire Norton in 2008. Garner denies wrongdoing and has said he considers himself a victim because he did not know he was dealing with fraudsters.
b1_text:
Here is the rewritten text at CEFR B1 level:

In the summer, the ombudsman made a decision. The ombudsman said the trustee did not act honestly. The trustee did not do his job well. He had a conflict of interest. He made money when he should not have. He did not act carefully.

This happened after an investigation by the Guardian and ITV News in January. The investigation showed that 228 workers lost all their pension money. Their money was used to buy Norton shares. They were tricked by a bad person.

Garner got the pension money in 2012 and 2013. A scam happened before this. A man named Simon Colfer sold the pension plan in a bad way. He was found guilty of fraud in 2018.

Two other people were involved with Garner. Their names are Andrew Meeson and Peter Bradley. They helped set up the Norton pension plan. They were found guilty of tax fraud in 2013. They took back 5 million pounds in tax. They said they paid money into pensions, but this was not true.

The court documents showed something else. They showed that Garner borrowed money to buy Norton in 2008. He borrowed 990,000 pounds. This money came from the fraud.

Garner says he did nothing wrong. He says he is a victim. He says he did not know he was working with bad people.

text: Black, Asian and minority ethnic (BAME) people are much more likely than white people to work in hospitality, one of the sectors hardest hit by the economic fallout of the pandemic as restaurants, bars and other venues have been shut for months during the lockdowns. About one in 12 (8%) workers from BAME backgrounds are employed in hospitality roles. That compares with about one in 20 (5%) white British workers, research from the Resolution Foundation shows. Overall, 300,000 people from BAME backgrounds work in hospitality. The thinktank’s report found that even before the pandemic hit, hospitality was one of the lowest paying sectors in the economy, with a typical hourly pay of £8.72. It said that 23% of hospitality workers were paid at or below the national living wage. The research found that BAME workers in the sector also faced “pay penalties” – pay gaps that account for workers’ age, qualifications, experience, and the kinds of jobs they do – relative to white British workers. “Crucially, these pay penalties are bigger than the raw pay gaps found in official earnings data – suggesting that the extent of disadvantage is bigger than previously thought,” the report said. BAME men were paid 65p an hour less than white British men on average, the report found. BAME women were also underpaid compared with white British women but the gap was less severe. The report found that while hospitality as a whole disproportionately employed young people – over a third of its workforce were aged 16-24 – this was not always the case for BAME workers. For example, the typical age of a Bangladeshi worker in hospitality was 42 – higher than the typical age for Bangladeshi workers across the whole economy (35), and higher than white British workers in hospitality (28). Indian workers in hospitality were among the highest paid ethnic group per hour (£8.96) and among the most likely to be in high-paying occupations (28%) such as hotel and restaurant managers. This corresponds with 41% of Indian hospitality workers holding a degree. In comparison, one in four Bangladeshi hospitality workers had no qualifications and typically earned 12% less than Indian hospitality workers, at £7.85 an hour.
b1_text:
People from Black, Asian and other ethnic groups (BAME) often work in restaurants and hotels. These places are called "hospitality."

The pandemic was very bad for hospitality. Restaurants and bars were closed for a long time. So, many people lost their jobs.

More BAME people work in hospitality than white people. About 8% of BAME workers are in hospitality. Only 5% of white British workers are in hospitality.

About 300,000 BAME people work in hospitality.

Before the pandemic, hospitality was not a high-paying job. The average pay was about £8.72 per hour. Some people earned even less than the living wage.

BAME workers in hospitality are sometimes paid less than white workers. This is even when they have the same age, skills and experience. This means BAME people face more problems than we thought.

BAME men earn less money per hour than white British men. The difference is about 65p per hour.

BAME women also earn less than white British women. But the difference is smaller.

Many young people work in hospitality. More than a third of workers are between 16 and 24 years old. But this is not always true for BAME workers.

For example, many Bangladeshi workers in hospitality are older. The average age is 42. This is older than other Bangladeshi workers (35). It is also older than white British workers in hospitality (28).

Indian workers in hospitality often earn more money. They earn about £8.96 per hour. Many of them have good jobs like manager. About 41% of Indian hospitality workers have a degree.

Bangladeshi workers in hospitality sometimes earn less. One in four has no qualifications. They earn about £7.85 per hour. This is about 12% less than Indian workers.

text: Nye Cominetti, the senior economist at the Resolution Foundation, said: “As workers from BAME backgrounds are disproportionately likely to work in hospitality, a significant number of workers risk moving into unemployment when the furlough scheme ends in the spring. “The government should bear that in mind for the jobs support programmes it is providing.” A report by the British Beer & Pubs Association and the consultancy Oxford Economics has previously warned that 291,000 jobs in the hospitality trade could be lost as a result of coronavirus restrictions. The forecast was based on industry data suggesting that 25% of pubs could close, with the remainder barely breaking even as they struggle to cope with reduced custom and limited opening hours. Oxford Economics said the worst-case scenario would reduce the sector’s economic output by £7.4bn and cut wages by £3.9bn.
b1_text:
Nye Cominetti works for the Resolution Foundation. He is an important economist there. He said something about workers.

Some workers are more likely to work in jobs like hotels and restaurants. These workers are often from BAME backgrounds. BAME means Black, Asian, and Minority Ethnic.

Many of these workers might lose their jobs. This could happen when the furlough scheme ends in the spring. The furlough scheme is when the government pays some of the workers' wages.

Nye Cominetti thinks the government should remember these workers. The government should help them with job support programs.

The British Beer & Pubs Association and Oxford Economics wrote a report. They said many jobs could be lost in the hospitality trade. The hospitality trade is about hotels, restaurants, and pubs.

They think about 291,000 jobs could be lost. This is because of the coronavirus rules.

They think many pubs might close. About 25% of pubs might close. The other pubs might not make much money. It is hard for them because they have fewer customers. They also have to close early.

Oxford Economics said things could be very bad. The economy could lose £7.4 billion. Workers could lose £3.9 billion in wages.

text: Family-owned Welsh brewer SA Brain & Co has handed over the running of its 156 pubs to Marston’s, saving 1,300 jobs, after the coronavirus pandemic threatened their closure. Brains, whose pubs are mainly based in south and west Wales, said it had come “under significant financial pressure” during the pandemic, as restrictions mean pubs must remain closed except for takeaway and delivery. The company closed its entire pub estate on 4 December after the announcement of a ban on alcohol sales and enforced 6pm closing across Wales to try to contain a worsening Covid-19 outbreak. Remaining open under those restrictions was “not a viable option”, Brains said. SA Brain & Co was established in 1882 in Cardiff, and became Wales’s biggest brewer and pubs company while remaining under family ownership. John Rhys, the company chairman who oversaw the deal, is the great-grandson of founder Samuel Arthur Brain. Before the pandemic, the pubs included in the deal made £14m a year in core earnings. Marston’s will take over the pubs in February, mostly under 25-year leases from Brains. The annual rent on the pubs was £5.5m. The pubs will be run under the Brains brand, and will continue to sell its beer, which is brewed at a facility in Cardiff Bay that was opened in March 2019. Before that Brains was made in breweries in Cardiff’s city centre. Rhys said: “We know and trust Marston’s to be excellent custodians of our pubs and, while this is not a decision we have taken lightly, we are confident that our pubs and our pubs teams will thrive under their stewardship. “Furthermore, this transaction enables Brains to recapitalise its balance sheet and continue its long heritage as an independent entity, preserving this great Welsh business for generations to come.” Marston’s, formerly known as Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries until a 2007 rebrand, runs about 1,400 pubs across the UK, including 106 in Wales. The 1,300 employees in Brains pubs will transfer to Marston’s, which employs a further 14,000 people across the UK.
b1_text:
A Welsh company called SA Brain & Co owns many pubs. These pubs are mostly in south and west Wales.

The company is a family business. It has been running for a long time.

But the coronavirus made things very hard. The pubs had to close because of the rules. They could only sell drinks to take away.

This made the company lose a lot of money. It was hard for them to keep going.

So, SA Brain & Co made a deal with another company called Marston's. Marston's will now run the 156 pubs.

This will save the jobs of 1,300 people who work in the pubs. If Marston's did not help, the pubs might have closed.

The boss of SA Brain & Co is John Rhys. He is the great-grandson of the person who started the company.

Before the coronavirus, the pubs made a lot of money each year. It was about £14 million.

Marston's will start running the pubs in February. They will rent the pubs from Brains for 25 years. The rent will be £5.5 million each year.

The pubs will still be called "Brains." They will still sell Brains beer. The beer is made in Cardiff Bay.

John Rhys said that he trusts Marston's to take good care of the pubs. He believes the pubs and the workers will do well with Marston's.

He also said that this deal will help Brains get back on its feet. It will help the company stay in business for a long time.

Marston's owns about 1,400 pubs in the UK. They also own 106 pubs in Wales.

The 1,300 people who work in Brains pubs will now work for Marston's. Marston's has 14,000 workers in the UK.

text: Ralph Findlay, the Marston’s chief executive, said the deal would be mutually beneficial and that it “strengthens our representation in south and west Wales, while protecting the heritage and independence of an iconic Welsh business”.
b1_text:
Ralph Findlay is the boss of a company called Marston's. He said they made a deal. He thinks the deal is good for both companies.

He also said it will help Marston's in Wales. They will have more places there. These places are in the south and west of Wales.

The deal will also keep a Welsh company safe. This company is important in Wales. It is old and special. The deal will help it stay Welsh and not change too much.

text: Britain’s independent shops had a sales boost in 2020 despite an overall drop in retail spending, as Covid travel restrictions and working from home prompted consumers to shop on local high streets instead of city centres. Data from Barclaycard shows spending at independent food and drink shops, including off-licences, butchers and bakeries, jumped 28.6% in 2020 compared with a year earlier. In contrast, total consumer spending fell 7.1%, as social distancing rules left shoppers with fewer opportunities to spend on overseas holidays, hospitality and in city centres. Barclaycard, which covers nearly half of the UK’s credit and debit card transactions, found that while spending on essential goods such as groceries rose by 4.1% compared with 2019, non-essential spending fell 11.3%. Department stores were particularly hard hit, with spending down 17.2%, while clothing retailers experienced a 15.6% slump, leading to the financial problems at the likes of Debenhams and the Topshop owner, Arcadia. However, bricks and mortar discounters had a 25.4% increase, as Britons facing furlough and job cuts sought value for money deals. Consumers forced to spend more time at home turned to DIY projects to spruce up their living space. Pent-up demand after the reopening of non-essential shops in June pushed overall spending at DIY and home goods stores up 9.8% for the year. Furniture retailers reported a 5.3% rise, as consumers invested in big ticket items. Britons treated themselves – as well as friends and family they could not see – to flowers throughout the year, with spending at florists rising 22.7%. Crafts and hobby spending increased 9.8%, and pets were given extra attention with vet and pet retail increasing 10.7%. But the report also shows how much restaurants suffered despite Rishi Sunak’s “eat out to help out” initiative over the summer. Restrictions throughout the rest of the year contributed to a 47% drop in restaurant spending, while bars and pubs took a 36.7% hit. However, Covid restrictions contributed to a 49.1% rise in spending on online takeaway orders, while meal subscription services jumped 62.4%. Demand for at-home entertainment pushed spending on digital subscriptions up 31.5%, while money spent on electronics including game consoles rose 10.8%.
b1_text:
In 2020, shops in Britain had a difficult time.
But some small, local shops did better than before.
This happened even though people spent less money overall.

The Covid virus made it hard to travel.
Many people worked from home.
So, people shopped in their local areas instead of big cities.

Barclaycard has information about how people spent money.
They found that people spent more money at small food shops.
These shops include places that sell beer, meat, and bread.
Spending at these shops went up by 28.6% in 2020.

But overall, people spent 7.1% less money than before.
This is because it was hard to go out and shop.
People could not go on holidays or visit restaurants as much.

Barclaycard said that people spent more money on things they needed.
For example, they spent 4.1% more on food from the supermarket.
But they spent 11.3% less on things they did not need.

Big shops called department stores had problems.
Spending there went down by 17.2%.
Shops that sold clothes also had problems.
Spending there went down by 15.6%.
This made it hard for some shops to stay open.

But shops with cheap prices did well.
Spending there went up by 25.4%.
This is because some people lost their jobs.
They wanted to find good deals.

People spent more time at home.
So, they started doing projects to fix up their houses.
When shops opened again in June, people bought things for their homes.
Spending at home improvement shops went up by 9.8%.

Shops that sold furniture also did well.
Spending there went up by 5.3%.
People bought big things for their homes.

People also bought flowers for themselves and their friends.
Spending at flower shops went up by 22.7%.
People spent more money on crafts and hobbies.
Spending there went up by 9.8%.
People also spent more money on their pets.

But restaurants had a difficult time.
The government tried to help with a special offer.
But restaurants still had problems.
Spending at restaurants went down by 47%.
Bars and pubs also had problems.
Spending there went down by 36.7%.

But people ordered more food online.
Spending on takeaway food went up by 49.1%.
More people used meal services that send food to their homes.
Spending on these services went up by 62.4%.

People also spent more money on things to do at home.
Spending on things like Netflix went up by 31.5%.
People spent more money on electronics like game consoles.
Spending there went up by 10.8%.

text: Meanwhile, general online retailers benefited from a 52.5% hike in spending. Raheel Ahmed, Barclaycard’s head of consumer products, said: “2020 has accelerated many trends. E-commerce has seen huge growth, working from home has meant many are shopping more locally, and experiences within the home, such as virtual workouts, have become the norm.” Travel spending, including on airlines and travel agents, tumbled 61.1% in August and 63.1% in September, as coronavirus restrictions and quarantine rules took their toll. “Hopefully with a vaccine being rolled out in 2021 we will see green shoots for the most severely impacted sectors,” Ahmed said. “Having said that, some of the trends and changes we have seen in customer habits may be here to stay.”
b1_text:
Online shops did very well. People spent 52.5% more money in these shops.

Raheel Ahmed works for Barclaycard. He said that 2020 changed many things quickly.

More people are buying things online. This is because of the changes. Working from home means people buy things near their houses. People are also doing things like online exercise at home.

Travel spending went down. People spent less money on planes and travel agents. It went down 61.1% in August and 63.1% in September. This is because of the virus rules. People had to stay home after traveling.

Ahmed hopes things will get better in 2021. He hopes the vaccine will help the travel companies. Some of the new ways people buy things may stay for a long time. He thinks some of these changes might not go away.

text: The plus-size clothing brand Evans has been bought out of administration in a £23m deal that will result in the closure of all its stores and concessions with the potential loss of hundreds of jobs . The chain is the first part of Sir Philip Green’s Arcadia Group to be sold off, marking the beginning of the breakup of his fashion empire, which also includes Topshop, Dorothy Perkins, Burton and Miss Selfridge. City Chic Collective, an Australian retailer, plans to operate Evans, which made sales of £26m online and via wholesale last year, as an online-only brand. That will mean the closure of more than 100 Evans concessions and outlets within other Arcadia stores. Five standalone stores will permanently close with the loss of 25 jobs. The concessions and other outlets will not close immediately but hundreds of jobs are at risk at those outlets. Arcadia, which employs 13,000 people at about 500 outlets, collapsed into administration last month as high street lockdowns prompted by the coronavirus pandemic piled on pressure after years of flagging sales amid heavy competition from rivals such as Boohoo and Primark. Bids for all the brands are due to be filed on Monday, with Topshop expected to attract offers of up to £200m. Bidders are thought to include the online specialist Boohoo, the fashion and homewares group Next, and Authentic Brands, the owner of the US department store Barneys. Mike Ashley’s Frasers Group, formerly known as Sports Direct, is also thought to be interested in the smaller Arcadia brands. Administrators from Deloitte said on Monday there had been “significant expressions of interest for all brands”. They said they did not expect to provide a further update on the process until January. City Chic Collective said it had bought Evans as part of a plan to extend its portfolio of plus-size brands, which include City Chic and Hips & Curves, into Europe. It operates in Australia, New Zealand and the US, where it bought the Avenue brand last year. The company already had a relationship with Evans, which has sold City Chic products via its website for the past five years. “Our vision has always been to lead a world of curves,” said Phil Ryan, the chief executive of City Chic Collective.
b1_text:
A company called Evans sells clothes for plus-size women. Evans had money problems. Now, another company called City Chic Collective has bought Evans for 23 million pounds.

This means that all Evans shops will close. Many people may lose their jobs.

Evans was part of a bigger group called Arcadia. Arcadia has other shops like Topshop and Dorothy Perkins. The man in charge of Arcadia is Sir Philip Green. Evans is the first shop from Arcadia to be sold. This is the start of Arcadia being broken up.

City Chic Collective is from Australia. They want to sell Evans clothes only online. Last year, Evans made 26 million pounds from online sales.

More than 100 Evans shops inside other Arcadia stores will close. Five Evans shops that are separate will also close. 25 people will lose their jobs in these shops. Many more jobs are at risk in the Evans shops inside other stores.

Arcadia has many shops and workers. But Arcadia had money problems. This was because of the coronavirus. The shops had to close. They also had problems selling things before, because other shops like Boohoo and Primark sold similar things.

Other companies want to buy the other shops in Arcadia. Topshop might be sold for 200 million pounds. Companies like Boohoo, Next, and Authentic Brands want to buy them. Mike Ashley's company, Frasers Group, might also buy some smaller shops from Arcadia.

The people in charge of selling Arcadia said many companies are interested in buying the shops. They will give more news about this in January.

City Chic Collective bought Evans because they want to sell more plus-size clothes in Europe. They already sell clothes in Australia, New Zealand, and America. They bought another brand called Avenue last year.

City Chic Collective and Evans already worked together. Evans sold City Chic clothes on their website.

The boss of City Chic Collective, Phil Ryan, said they want to be the best at selling clothes for plus-size women.

text: “From modern fashion to casual apparel, intimates and footwear, designing fashion for the curvy woman that fits and flatters, is all we do.”
b1_text:
Here is the text rewritten for a B1 level English learner:

We make clothes. We make fashion clothes. We also make clothes for every day. We make underwear and shoes too.

We design fashion for curvy women. This is all we do. Our clothes fit well. They make women look good.

text: Retail sales fell by 3.8% in November on the previous month as the coronavirus lockdown in England and restrictions elsewhere in the UK shut much of the high street. Ending a six-month run of rising sales, the figures revealed the impact of the pandemic on the sector as the infection rate increased across the country. A 19% fall in clothing sales followed the closure of most department stores and non-essential shops. A government message that workers should stay at home if they could caused car journeys to slump and petrol sales to follow suit, with a 16.6% decline. The only bright spot for retailers was an increase in the sale of household goods of 1.6% as shoppers went online to stock up for Christmas. Supermarkets and food stores increased sales by 3.1%. Analysts said it was no surprise the lockdown bolstered online shopping to a record total of 31.4% of all spending, after an increase of almost 75% since November 2019. The Office for National Statistics said 90% of businesses continued to trade in some form through the month, mostly via a click-and-collect service. But only 68.8% of department stores continued trading. Meanwhile, many online retailers reported a boom in sales, as they did during the UK-wide lockdown in spring, though heavy discounting helped to keep the tills ringing. The ONS said this week price-cutting by clothing retailers last month pushed UK inflation down to 0.3%, from 0.7% a month earlier. The Bank of England’s inflation target is 2%. Aled Patchett, the head of retail at Lloyds Bank, said: “November’s sales highlight once again the polarising effect of Covid-19 on retail. Sectors like grocery and homeware perform well – and should be expected to have a strong finish to the year – while others including big-name high street brands fall foul of significantly reduced footfall. “Despite most shoppers having wrapped up their Covid Christmas shopping online this year, shops – particularly in smaller towns – will be hoping that the vaccine rollout inspires greater consumer confidence in the new year as people return to city centres for both work and play.” In October, a 6.4% increase in online sales spurred a 1.2% rise in the total volume of retail spending, mainly driven by shoppers rushing to buy early Christmas presents before the second lockdown in England.
b1_text:
In November, shops sold less things. Sales went down by 3.8% compared to last month. This is because there was a lockdown in England. Some other places in the UK also had rules that closed many shops.

Sales had been going up for six months. But now, the virus has made things bad for shops. More people were getting sick in the country.

Clothes shops sold much less. Sales went down 19%. This is because many big shops and other shops that sell things that people do not need were closed.

The government said people should work from home if they can. So, people did not drive their cars much. Petrol sales went down too. They went down by 16.6%.

But some shops did well. Shops that sell things for the house sold more. Sales went up 1.6%. People bought things online for Christmas. Supermarkets and food shops also sold more. Sales went up 3.1%.

Experts said it was not a surprise that online shopping was popular. It was the highest ever, with 31.4% of all shopping. Online shopping has gone up a lot since last year. It went up almost 75% since November 2019.

The Office for National Statistics said that most shops were still open in some way. About 90% of shops let people buy things online and pick them up. But only 68.8% of big shops were still open.

Many online shops sold a lot. This also happened when the UK was in lockdown before. They had sales with low prices to sell more.

The Office for National Statistics also said that clothes shops had low prices last month. This made prices in the UK go down to 0.3%. Before, they were 0.7%. The Bank of England wants prices to go up by 2%.

Aled Patchett from Lloyds Bank said that the virus is making things good for some shops and bad for others. Shops that sell food and things for the house are doing well. But shops that sell other things are doing badly because not many people are going to the shops.

He also said that people are buying Christmas presents online. Shops hope that the vaccine will make people feel better. They hope people will go back to the city to work and have fun.

In October, online sales went up a lot. This made all sales go up by 1.2%. People were buying Christmas presents early because they knew there would be another lockdown in England.

text: Lee Lucas, the chief executive of the Fashion Retail Academy, which has partnerships with some of Britain’s biggest retailers including Marks & Spencer and Next, said he was not surprised the November lockdown triggered a fall in clothing sales. “November is one the busiest months of the year for retailers, so this emergency measure by the government will have been directly responsible for the unusually high level of discounting currently in stores, with shops fighting for every consumer in the briefest of run-ups to Christmas.”
b1_text:
Lee Lucas is the boss of the Fashion Retail Academy. This school works with big shops in Britain. Marks & Spencer and Next are some of them.

Lee Lucas said he was not surprised that clothes sales went down in November. This happened because of the lockdown.

November is usually a very busy month for shops. But the government made a rule to close shops. This rule made shops sell things for less money.

Shops are trying hard to get people to buy things before Christmas. They are fighting for every customer. They don't have much time.

text: The UK public’s appetite for eating out has plunged to its weakest since the spring amid growing evidence of the impact of the Omicron variant on the hospitality sector during its crucial pre-Christmas period. The number of seated diners fell by 14 percentage points in the week ending 20 December to 88% of the level in the same period of 2019, before the start of the pandemic, according to the weekly digest of flash economic indicators from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Using data from the online restaurant booking site OpenTable and other sources, the ONS said Britons were eating out less and working from home more in response to rising infection rates and the government’s plan B measures. Amid widespread reports of bookings being cancelled, the drop in the number of diners in the latest week was the sharpest since early September and the lowest level since restaurants reopened indoors in England, Scotland and Wales in May after last winter’s lockdown. It was also the first time the weekly comparison with 2019 has dropped below 100% since May. Restaurants in London have been especially hard hit by Omicron, with the number of diners in the latest week falling 18 points to 57% of the level in the same period of 2019. In Manchester, despite an eight-point drop on the week, the number of diners stood at 104% of the level in the run-up to Christmas 2019. The ONS said the number of firms reporting staff working from home in the latest two weeks had risen by two points to 14%, with a marked impact on businesses reliant on consumers. Transactions at Pret a Manger sandwich outlets were lower in the week ending 16 December than in January 2020 in six of seven urban locations, with London again the most affected city. While trade in regional towns remained above pre-pandemic levels, sales in the capital dropped by 29 points to barely 50% of the January 2020 level. The ONS report showed retailers doing less badly than restaurants, with footfall in the latest week 81% of its 2019 level – a drop of only one percentage point. Credit and debt card payment purchases were up 4% on a year ago. Earlier this week, the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, announced an emergency £1bn package to help businesses struggling with the impact of Omicron.
b1_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a CEFR B1 level:

People in the UK are not eating out as much. This is the worst it has been since the spring. This is because of the Omicron virus. It is affecting restaurants before Christmas.

The number of people eating in restaurants went down. It went down by 14%. This was in the week ending December 20th. It is now 88% of what it was in 2019. 2019 was before the virus started. This information comes from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). They look at the economy every week.

The ONS uses information from OpenTable and other places. OpenTable is a website for booking restaurants. The ONS said people are eating out less. They are also working from home more. This is because there are more people getting sick. The government also has new rules to stop the virus. These are called "Plan B".

Many people are cancelling their restaurant bookings. The number of people eating in restaurants went down a lot this week. It was the biggest drop since September. It is the lowest number since restaurants opened again. Restaurants opened in England, Scotland, and Wales in May. They were closed because of the virus last winter. This is also the first time the numbers have gone below 2019 since May.

Restaurants in London are having a hard time. The number of people eating in restaurants went down by 18%. It is now 57% of what it was in 2019. In Manchester, the number of people eating in restaurants is better. It went down by 8%. But it is still 104% of what it was before Christmas in 2019.

The ONS said more people are working from home. 14% of companies said their staff are working from home. This is 2% more than before. This is making it hard for businesses that need customers.

People are buying less from Pret a Manger. Pret a Manger sells sandwiches. In six cities, sales were lower than in January 2020. London is the worst. Sales in London went down by 29%. They are only 50% of what they were in January 2020.

Shops are doing better than restaurants. The number of people going to shops is 81% of what it was in 2019. This is only a small drop. People are using credit cards more. They are buying 4% more than last year.

Rishi Sunak is a government worker. He is helping businesses that are having trouble. He is giving them money to help with the problems caused by the virus. He is giving 1 billion pounds.

text: Meanwhile, analysts are warning that the economy is likely to contract in December even if restrictions in England remain unchanged. Andrew Goodwin, a UK economist at the consultancy firm Oxford Economics, said: “Though the government has opted to defer a decision on introducing further restrictions until after Christmas, it seems likely that a mix of greater consumer caution and reduced mobility will ensure that the UK’s GDP falls in December.”
b1_text:
Here's the rewritten text at CEFR B1 level:

Experts are saying something important about the economy. They think the economy will get smaller in December. This is even if the rules in England stay the same.

Andrew Goodwin works for a company called Oxford Economics. He studies the economy in the UK. He said something about this.

He said the government might not make new rules before Christmas. But people are careful now. They don't want to spend too much money. They also move around less. Because of this, the UK's money, or GDP, will go down in December.

text: Ikea has increased the price of its flat-pack furniture by up to 50%, blaming supply chain costs caused by Covid-19, in a move that will further stoke growing concern about the rising cost of living. After customers complained that prices appeared to have risen sharply after Christmas, the retailer said it was no longer able to absorb increased costs and was passing them on to consumers. An Ikea spokesperson tweeted: “Unfortunately, there has been a significant increase in costs across the supply chain, including in raw materials, transport and logistics. As this is still ongoing, it is necessary to increase prices across many of our products.” Archived versions of Ikea’s website from as recently as October showed significant price increases, including a Malm desk that has gone up from £99 to £150, a jump of more than 50%. A Jokkmokk table with four chairs is also up 50%, from £99 to £149, compared with earlier this year. A Hemnes daybed has gone up from £215 to £279, a 30% rise, while an Alex nine-drawer unit increased 35% from £85 to £115, according to archived versions of the Ikea website from earlier this year. A Kura children’s bed was up by 14% from £129 to £150, while Ikea’s Klippan sofa, one of the Swedish store’s most popular items, is £20 more expensive – a rise of 11% – at £199. Ikea confirmed that the company had raised prices across multiple countries and ranges. A spokesperson said: “Since the start of the pandemic, Ikea has managed to absorb the significant cost increases experienced across the supply chain while keeping prices as low and stable as we possibly can. Now, like many other retailers, we have had to raise our prices to mitigate the impact on our business. “Price increases vary but remain in line with what we are seeing globally at Ikea, which is approximately a 9% average increase across countries and the product range. Affordability remains at the heart of our business, and our focus will always be on continuing to offer quality, sustainable home furnishings at an affordable price for the many people.” Ikea warned earlier this year that prices would rise, citing factors including bottlenecks in shipping raw materials from Asia to Europe.
b1_text:
Ikea sells furniture that you build yourself. Recently, Ikea made their furniture more expensive.

Some prices went up a lot, as much as 50%. This means things now cost much more money.

People are worried because the cost of living is going up. It is becoming more expensive to buy things.

Customers said that Ikea prices went up a lot after Christmas. Ikea said that it costs more to make and move their furniture.

Ikea said they can't pay for these extra costs themselves anymore. So, they are making customers pay more.

An Ikea person wrote online that it costs more for materials, transport, and moving things. They said prices for many things will go up.

Old versions of the Ikea website show that prices have changed. A desk called Malm used to cost £99. Now it costs £150. This is more than 50% more expensive.

A table with chairs called Jokkmokk used to cost £99. Now it costs £149. This is also 50% more.

A bed called Hemnes used to cost £215. Now it costs £279. This is 30% more.

A set of drawers called Alex used to cost £85. Now it costs £115. This is 35% more.

A bed for children called Kura used to cost £129. Now it costs £150. This is 14% more.

A sofa called Klippan is now £20 more expensive. It costs £199 now.

Ikea said that they have raised prices in many countries and for many different types of furniture.

Ikea said that since the start of the Covid problem, they have tried to keep prices low. But now, they have to raise prices like other shops.

The price increases are different for each item. But Ikea said the average price increase is about 9%.

Ikea says they want to keep furniture at a good price. They will try to offer good furniture that people can buy without spending too much money.

Earlier this year, Ikea said that prices would go up. They said it was because it was hard to move materials from Asia to Europe.

text: The wider furniture industry has suffered significant delays, with the online furniture retailer Made.com saying that up to £45m-worth of orders have been delayed. It blamed a profit warning on factory shutdowns in Vietnam, clogged ports and extended shipping times. Rising prices at Ikea come amid broader concern about the cost of living, after UK inflation hit a 10-year high of 5.1% in November. Soaring energy bills and rising taxes prompted 2022 to be dubbed the “year of the squeeze” by a thinktank report published this week.
b1_text:
Here's the rewritten text at CEFR B1 level:

Furniture shops are having problems. A shop called Made.com sells furniture online. They said many orders are late. The value of these late orders is about 45 million pounds.

They said the problem is because factories in Vietnam closed. Also, ports are busy and ships take a long time. This is making it hard to get furniture.

Ikea is also raising prices. People are worried about the cost of things. Prices in the UK went up a lot. It is the highest in 10 years. The price increase was 5.1% in November.

Energy bills are going up. Taxes are also rising. A report said 2022 will be a hard year for money. People will have less money to spend.

text: The government is to hold emergency meetings with the bosses of the UK’s biggest energy suppliers, after providers warned on Thursday of a “national crisis” that could lead bills to increase by more than 50% to £2,000 a year. Kwasi Kwarteng, the business secretary, is to hold virtual meetings on Monday with energy suppliers, who are pushing the government to intervene to alleviate the unprecedented rises in consumers’ bills caused by soaring wholesale gas prices. The energy industry believes the crisis, during which more than 26 energy suppliers have gone bust at a cost of £1.8bn to date, could be made more manageable if the government axed the 5% VAT on bills imposed when the UK was part of the European Union. Other interventions the industry would like to see considered include extending fuel grants and moving green levies from consumers’ bills into taxation. Trade body Energy UK said on Thursday that consumers could expect their bills to soar by as much as 50% from 1 April. While wholesale prices continue to climb steeply, the UK’s price cap on energy bills stops companies from immediately passing those costs on to their customers. The price cap, set by the industry regulator, Ofgem, has been at a record £1,277 Since 1 October. Ofgem is expected to raise the cap significantly on 1 April. EDF has said the cap could hit £2,000 by next October, when the cap is reviewed again. Analysts at Investec believe the expected bill increase in April would add 1.8 percentage points to inflation next year. On Thursday, the shadow energy minister, Ed Miliband, called on the government to stop families being “clobbered” with the increased cost of heating and powering their homes, by removing VAT on bills for six months. Spain has cut energy taxes, while Germany has slashed green levies on household bills, designed to support the development of renewable energy. But Energy UK said measures like these would save less than £300, significantly less than the expected £600 rise in the average annual bill when the price cap goes up. One plan being formulated by the energy industry to would involve a government-administered loan scheme to spread the impact of the price increases over several years.
b1_text:
The government will have important meetings soon. These meetings are with the people in charge of the biggest energy companies in the UK.

Energy companies say there is a big problem in the country. They think energy bills could go up a lot. Bills could go up by more than 50%. This means some people could pay £2,000 a year.

Kwasi Kwarteng is in charge of business for the government. He will talk to the energy companies online on Monday. The energy companies want the government to help. They want the government to do something about the high cost of energy for people. The cost of gas has gone up a lot. This is why energy bills are going up.

Many energy companies have closed down. This has cost £1.8 billion so far. The energy companies think the government could make things better. They want the government to stop charging VAT on energy bills. VAT is a tax of 5%. The UK had this tax when it was part of Europe.

The energy companies also want the government to give people more money for fuel. They also want the government to pay for green energy in a different way. Green energy is good for the environment.

Energy UK is a group that speaks for energy companies. They said that bills could go up a lot from April 1. They said they could go up by as much as 50%.

The price of gas is still going up. But the UK has a limit on how much energy companies can charge. This limit is called a price cap. The companies cannot charge people more than this limit right away.

Ofgem sets the price cap. Ofgem is in charge of the energy industry. The price cap is now £1,277. It has been this price since October 1. Ofgem will probably raise the price cap a lot on April 1.

One energy company, EDF, thinks the price cap could be £2,000 by next October. They will check the price cap again then.

Some experts think that if bills go up in April, the price of things in the shops will also go up. This could make things 1.8% more expensive.

Ed Miliband is in charge of energy for the other main political party. He wants the government to stop people from paying so much for heating and electricity. He wants the government to stop charging VAT on energy bills for six months.

Spain has also cut taxes on energy. Germany has also cut costs for green energy for people's homes.

Energy UK says these things will not save people much money. They said it will save less than £300. But bills could go up by £600 a year.

The energy companies have a plan. They want the government to give them money. Then they will not have to raise bills so much at once. They can raise them slowly over many years.

text: The plan would involve one or more commercial lenders – such as banks – covering the immediate cost of buying energy on wholesale markets at record prices, with a sum of at least £7bn. The loans would not require a government guarantee, but officials would be responsible for ensuring repayments. “We regularly engage with the energy industry and will continue to ensure that consumers are protected through the energy price cap, which is insulating millions from record global gas prices,” a government spokesperson said. “We also continue to support those most in need through our £500mhousehold support fund, the warm home discount and winter fuel payments.”
b1_text:
Here is the text rewritten at a CEFR B1 level:

There is a plan about energy. It needs money to buy energy. The energy costs a lot right now.

Banks can give money to buy energy. These banks are called lenders. They can give about £7 billion. This money will pay for the energy.

The government will not promise to pay back the loans. But the government will make sure the banks get their money back.

A person from the government said: "We talk to energy companies a lot. We want to protect people. We have a limit on how much energy can cost. This helps many people because energy prices are very high."

The government person also said: "We help people who need it most. We have a fund of £500 million to help them. We also have discounts for heating homes. And we give money to help pay for heating in the winter."

text: On Thursday the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, gave a mid-year economic update predicting a solid economic bounceback from Covid restrictions. We’ve looked under the hood to see what the treasury’s crystal ball says is in store for the economy, what might go wrong, and how government finances will fare if they’re right. Forecasts The budget papers project the Australian economy will grow in real terms by 3.75% in 2021-22 and 3.5% in 2022-23, before easing back to 2.25% and 2.5% in the final two years of the forward projections. The unemployment rate is tipped to fall to 4.25% in that time. The treasury thinks Australians will be ambitious with their pay demands and bosses generous in a bid to keep workers, because wages growth is supposed to take off from 2.25% in 2021-22 to 3.25% in 2024-25. Inflation is projected to reach and stay at the mid-point of the reserve bank’s target range (2.5%) in 2022-23. Assumptions The treasury has assumed that with more than 80% of Australians aged 16 and above now vaccinated, rates will climb to more than 90%. So far so good. But the rest of the assumptions are … a little rosy. The treasury assumed lockdowns will no longer be required, with “most domestic activity restrictions” lifted by the start of 2022 and only basic density restrictions in place. There may be “temporary strengthening of activity restrictions” to contain localised outbreaks – but these short, sharp lockdown-like restrictions are assumed to have no material impact on the outlook. Remaining state border restrictions are assumed to be lifted by early 2022 and the Omicron variant “is not assumed to significantly alter current reopening plans or require a reimposition of widespread health and activity restrictions”. Migrants will start returning from 2022, with international students ready to go for the first semester of next year. What could go wrong In a word: Covid. If a new variant of concern emerges (beyond Omicron) requiring more significant health responses, the international border could be closed for another six months and public health orders and precautionary behaviour could drive down spending.
b1_text:
On Thursday, a man named Josh Frydenberg talked about the economy. He said the economy will get better after the Covid problems. He thinks things will be good for the economy.

We looked at what the government thinks will happen. We wanted to know what the future might be like for the economy. We also wanted to know what problems could happen. We checked how the government will do with money if the predictions are right.

The government thinks the economy will grow. It will grow by 3.75% this year. Next year, it will grow by 3.5%. After that, the growth will be a little slower. It will be 2.25% and then 2.5% in the next two years.

The government also thinks fewer people will be without jobs. The number of people without jobs will go down to 4.25%.

The government thinks people will want more money. They think bosses will give workers more money to keep them working there. So, wages will increase. This year, wages will grow by 2.25%. In a few years, wages will grow by 3.25%.

The government thinks prices will go up a little. The price increase will be 2.5% in 2022-23. This is the middle of what the bank wants.

The government is making some guesses about the future. They think that most people will get the vaccine. They think over 90% of people will get it.

But the other guesses might be too good to be true. The government thinks there will be no more lockdowns. They think most rules will be gone by the start of 2022. There will only be a few simple rules.

Maybe there will be some small rules to stop the virus in some places. But the government thinks these small rules will not hurt the economy.

The government thinks the borders between states will open soon, by early 2022. They also think the new virus, Omicron, will not change the plan to open up. They think it will not make the government put back the old rules.

The government thinks students from other countries will come back in 2022. They will be ready for school next year.

What could go wrong? Covid. If a new virus comes, it could be bad. If the new virus needs more rules to stop it, the borders could close again. People might be scared and not spend money.

text: The treasury projects this could mean 1% is shaved off gross domestic product in 2021-22, and unemployment is about 1% higher. The rebound would instead come in the second half of 2022. The papers also note that revenue assumptions and nominal GDP are also sensitive to changes in the iron ore price, with a US$10 fall shaving $3.9bn off GDP this year and $0.9bn off tax receipts next financial year. If the government has to pay higher interest rates on bonds, then debt could blow out by a further 5.4% of GDP by 2032. $16bn of mystery spending The budget papers reveal that there is about $16bn of mystery spending over the next four years, consisting of decisions taken but not announced, or measures for which the cost is not-for-publication. That’s more than 10 times the size of mystery spending last year. The papers make it impossible to calculate the size of the war chest for announcements to be made before the election, by mixing in a bunch of commercially sensitive spending items like vaccine purchases. But a treasury official in the lockup suggested it was about half and half … so, an $8bn war chest for the election. There will also be $940m more revenue collected due to decisions taken but not announced or not for publication measures. Debt and deficit For a government previously concerned with the debt and deficit disaster, there is still red as far as the eye can see. The deficit is tipped to be $99.2bn in 2021-22, an improvement of $7.4bn since the budget despite the Delta lockdowns. The deficit will still be $57.5bn in 2024-25 (or 2.3% of GDP), and only shrinks to 1.8% of GDP in 2031-32. Net debt is projected to be 30.6% of GDP at June 2022, rising to a peak of 37.4% in 2025, then down to 35.5% in 2032. The papers say that despite the economic recovery the government is sticking with the first plank of its budget plan – strong and sustained recovery – so don’t expect austerity measures to try to cut the debt and deficit.
b1_text:
The government thinks the economy will be a little worse. This could mean the country makes 1% less money in 2021 and 2022. Also, more people could be out of work, about 1%.

The economy should get better in the second half of 2022. The price of iron ore is important. If the price goes down by $10, the country will make $3.9 billion less this year. Next year, the government will get $0.9 billion less in taxes.

The government sells bonds to get money. If the government has to pay more interest on these bonds, the country's debt could get much bigger. It could be 5.4% more of the country's money by 2032.

There is also some money that is not explained. The government will spend about $16 billion over the next four years. We do not know what it is for. It is much more than last year.

It is hard to know how much money the government has for the election. They have mixed it with other spending, like buying vaccines. But someone from the government said about half of the $16 billion could be for the election. That would be $8 billion.

The government will also get $940 million more money. This is because of decisions they made, but did not tell people about.

The government used to worry a lot about debt and not having enough money. But they still do not have enough money. The country will be short $99.2 billion in 2021 and 2022. This is a little better than before.

In 2024 and 2025, the country will still be short $57.5 billion. This is 2.3% of the country's money. In 2031 and 2032, it will be 1.8%.

The country's debt is getting bigger. It will be 30.6% of the country's money in June 2022. In 2025, it will be 37.4%. Then it will go down to 35.5% in 2032.

The government says the economy is getting better. But they will still try to make the economy strong. They will not try to save money and cut the debt right now.

text: Britons are many times more likely to have experienced shortages of food and fuel than people in half a dozen EU member states, according to a poll. Global supply chain problems prompted by the pandemic have disrupted the international trade network since the summer, with transport backlogs combining with labour shortages to create scarcities of various goods around the world. The government has argued that the shortages are part of a worldwide pattern and no worse in the UK than elsewhere, although logistics experts and other professionals – particularly in the food sector - have said the problems are amplified in Britain by a shortage of east European workers, including drivers, since Brexit. The YouGov poll showed residents of the UK were multiple times more likely to have experienced, or to know people who have experienced, shortages of food and fuel than people in France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Sweden and Denmark, and somewhat more likely to have experienced them than those in the US. Asked in early December whether they had personally experienced any scarcity of foodstuffs in recent weeks, 56% of respondents in the UK said yes, while 9% said they had not personally experienced any but knew people who had. The corresponding figures in the US were 49% and 10%, but in continental Europe, the proportion of people who said they had been personally affected was between three and nine times lower: 18% in Germany, 16% in France, 12% in Sweden, 8% in Denmark, 7% and 6% in Italy. The proportion saying they knew people who had experienced food shortages ranged from 13% in France to 8% in Denmark and Italy – where 58% of respondents said they were not even aware that supply chain problems had led to food shortages. The UK was also the only country where substantial numbers of people said they had experienced fuel shortages in recent weeks, since the crisis in September and October. One in three Britons (33%) said they had personally experienced a recent scarcity of fuel, compared with no more than 10% in any other country. Only 8% of German respondents, 7% of those in France and 5% of those in Italy said they had been personally experienced fuel scarcity, with 37%, 38% and 53% respectively saying they had not even heard of the issue – compared with just 11% of respondents in Britain.
b1_text:
Here is the rewritten text, targeting a CEFR B1 (Elementary) level:

A survey asked people about food and fuel. It showed that people in the UK had problems getting food and fuel more often. This happened more than in some countries in Europe.

The problem is about how things are moved around the world. This problem started because of the sickness. It made it hard to move things. There were not enough workers to move things. This made it hard to find some things.

The UK government said that this problem is all over the world. They said the UK is not worse than other places.

But some people who know about moving things disagree. They said the UK has more problems. This is because there are fewer workers from Europe since Brexit. Brexit is when the UK left the European Union.

The survey asked people if they had problems getting food. It also asked if they knew people who had problems. 56% of people in the UK said they had problems getting food. 9% said they did not have problems, but they knew people who did.

In the USA, 49% of people said they had problems. 10% said they knew people who did.

In some countries in Europe, fewer people had problems. 18% of people in Germany had problems. 16% of people in France had problems. 12% of people in Sweden had problems. 8% of people in Denmark had problems. Only 7% of people in Italy had problems. And 6% in Spain.

Some people in Europe knew others with food problems. 13% of people in France knew someone. 8% of people in Denmark and Italy knew someone. But in Italy, 58% of people did not even know there was a problem with food.

The UK was also the only country where many people had problems getting fuel. This happened in September and October. One in three people in the UK (33%) had problems getting fuel. In other countries, much fewer people had problems. In Germany, only 8% had problems. In France, only 7% had problems. In Italy, only 5% had problems.

Also, many people in Europe did not know about the fuel problem. 37% of people in Germany did not know. 38% of people in France did not know. 53% of people in Italy did not know. In the UK, only 11% of people did not know about the fuel problem.

text: Just Eat has entered the fast grocery delivery market by partnering with Asda in its first tie-up with a supermarket in the UK. From January, Just Eat customers will be able to add a range of products to their baskets starting with five Asda stores, with the exact locations to be announced in the new year. “We live in an on-demand world,” said Andrew Kenny, the UK managing director of Just Eat. “We want to make sure we are getting our customers the food they want, when they want, when they want it. Our tie-up with Asda means we can help people access everything from store cupboard essentials to fresh groceries in a matter of minutes.” Just Eat follows rivals Deliveroo and Uber Eats, which already have fast delivery deals with some of the UK’s biggest supermarkets. Best-known for restaurant and fast food delivery, Just Eat said that up to 1,000 grocery items would be made available for customers to order seven days a week. The two companies anticipate the partnership to be extended to more Asda stores throughout next year. The partnership builds on an existing relationship, with Just Eat delivering pizzas and meal deals from Asda Kitchen, the grocer’s indoor cafe and diner, which operates at 42 locations nationwide. “We’re always looking for new ways to offer customers more choice and extend the number of delivery options available,” said Simon Gregg, the vice-president of online grocery at Asda. “The trial will also see Asda become more accessible to a wider customer base through Just Eat’s significant presence in the on-demand food delivery space.” Just Eat has more than 60,000 restaurant partners it offers a delivery service for, covering 95% of the UK. The food delivery service has more than 10,000 grocery and convenience store partners on its platform internationally, including brands such as Spar, Shell and 7-Eleven. Last month, Asda appointed Stuart Rose, the Conservative peer and former boss of Marks & Spencer, as chairman.
b1_text:
Just Eat is now selling groceries. They are working with a big shop called Asda. This is the first time they work with a supermarket in the UK.

From January, people can buy things from Asda on Just Eat. They can add food and other things to their shopping basket.

It will start with five Asda shops. We will know the exact places next year.

Andrew Kenny works for Just Eat in the UK. He said people want things quickly. Just Eat wants to give people the food they want, when they want it.

Working with Asda means people can get food and other important things quickly. They can get them in a few minutes.

Other companies like Deliveroo and Uber Eats also sell groceries. They already work with big shops in the UK.

Just Eat is known for delivering food from restaurants. Now, they will also sell groceries. People can buy up to 1,000 different things. They can order seven days a week.

The two companies think they will work together in more Asda shops next year.

Just Eat already delivers pizzas and meals from Asda. Asda has cafes in 42 shops.

Simon Gregg works for Asda. He said they want to give people more choices. They also want more ways to deliver things.

This test will help more people find Asda. Just Eat is a big company for delivering food.

Just Eat works with more than 60,000 restaurants. They deliver to most places in the UK (95%).

Just Eat also works with more than 10,000 grocery shops around the world. These shops include Spar, Shell and 7-Eleven.

Last month, Asda hired Stuart Rose to be in charge. He used to work for Marks & Spencer.

text: European markets have taken something of a fright before Christmas on Monday thanks to concerns about new restrictions to tackle the omicron variant - and Wall Street has followed their lead. Here are the opening snaps from the three main US benchmark stock indices: S&P 500 DOWN 59.17 POINTS, OR 1.28%, AT 4,561.47 NASDAQ DOWN 227.60 POINTS, OR 1.50%, AT 14,942.08 DOW JONES DOWN 455.76 POINTS, OR 1.29%, AT 34,909.68 The mood has improved somewhat over the course of the day, however. The FTSE 100 has fallen by 0.9% to just over 7,200 points - but that is an improvement over the first few hours of trading. The pound has recovered against the US dollar - it is almost flat for the day at about $1.3235. Here are some of the other notable business events from today: Rolls-Royce won the backing of Qatar for small modular nuclear reactors. A $10bn spreadsheet error was among the reasons for a £47m Standard Chartered fine. Ex-Tesco boss Sir Dave Lewis was appointed to lead GSK’s consumer products spinout, which is expected to become one of the FTSE 100’s biggest companies. UK pubs and restaurants have warned of plummeting sales and “decimated” bookings. Data showed UK high streets have also suffered markedly, with falling sales in what should have been their most profitable weekend. The annual shindig for corporate types at Davos has been postponed for the second year in a row. Cruise ship company Carnival has said it will be back to 2019 earnings before various costs by 2023 - but that the first half of 2022 could result in another loss. You can continue to follow the Guardian’s coverage from around the world on our homepage and via our live blogs: In the UK, Boris Johnson and ministers are meeting to consider further coronavirus restrictions for England In our global coronavirus coverage, Thailand is considering ending quarantine-free travel, and the EU is set to back the Novavax vaccine The bounce on European stock markets has run out, it seems.
b1_text:
The markets in Europe were worried on Monday before Christmas. This was because of new rules about the Omicron virus. The markets in America also became worried.

Here is how the main markets in the US started:

*   S&P 500: Down by 59 points, about 1%. It is now at 4,561 points.
*   NASDAQ: Down by 227 points, about 1%. It is now at 14,942 points.
*   DOW JONES: Down by 455 points, about 1%. It is now at 34,909 points.

But the mood got a little better during the day.

The FTSE 100 in London went down by 0.9%. It is a little over 7,200 points. But this is better than earlier today.

The British pound is now worth about the same as yesterday compared to the US dollar. It is about $1.32.

Here are some other important business news from today:

*   Rolls-Royce got money from Qatar for small, new nuclear reactors.
*   Standard Chartered bank had to pay money because of a mistake. The mistake was in a big spreadsheet and it was worth $10 billion. The bank had to pay £47 million.
*   The old boss of Tesco, Dave Lewis, will now lead a new company. This company will make products for people. It used to be part of GSK. People think this company will be one of the biggest in the UK.
*   Pubs and restaurants in the UK said they are selling less food and drinks. Many people have canceled their bookings.
*   Shops in the UK did not sell much last weekend. This is bad because it should have been a good weekend for sales.
*   A big meeting for business people in Davos is canceled again. This is the second year in a row.
*   The cruise company Carnival said they will make as much money in 2023 as they did in 2019 (before costs). But they might lose money in the first half of 2022.

You can read more news on the Guardian website.

*   In the UK, the government is talking about new rules for coronavirus.
*   Thailand might stop letting people travel without having to stay in a hotel. The EU might approve a new vaccine called Novavax.

The markets in Europe are not getting better now. They are going down again.

text: The FTSE 100 is wavering around a 1.1% decline for the day - perhaps it is waiting for direction from the UK cabinet, which is about to meet. However, any leaks (or indeed official messages) are likely to come very near the end of the trading day, if not after. The Dax in Germany is down by 1.8% and France’s Cac 40 has lost 1.1%. The Stoxx 600, which combines all of the above and more, is down by 1.5%. Britain’s largest pub chain JD Wetherspoon has appointed two employees to its board in response to criticisms of its corporate governance. Four out of about 100 managers of Spoons pubs were chosen after shareholders and employees said it would “benefit from having more pub experience at board level”, the company said on Monday. Debbie Whittingham, a regional manager for the West Midlands, and Hudson Simmons, area manager for Sheffield, will join the board, while another two will be “associate employee directors”. Tim Martin, Wetherspoon’s founder and chairman, has previously lashed out at those who have criticised the company’s corporate governance in lengthy letters published on the stock market’s news service. However, he said: Pub and area managers, and other members of pub teams, have always participated in weekly decision-making meetings, which distil suggestions from the ‘front line’. The appointment of employee directors will extend this approach to board meetings and will help to preserve the culture of the company for the future. It was cautiously welcomed by the High Pay Centre, a thinktank focused on pay, corporate governance. Luke Hildyard, the High Pay Centre’s executive director, said: The perspectives workers directors can offer in terms of improvements to customer service and employee relations are obvious. The new Wetherspoons directors would have more credibility and independence if they’d been elected by colleagues rather than appointed by existing board members and it should also be remembered that boardroom representation is a complement not a substitute for full trade union rights and recognition. But this is a positive step by Wetherspoons that will benefit both workers and shareholders in the long term. One to watch on the UK politics front: the prime minister has called a cabinet meeting at 2pm.
b1_text:
The FTSE 100 is going down. It has gone down about 1.1% today. Maybe it is waiting to see what the UK government will do. The UK government is meeting soon.

If any news comes from the meeting, it will be late in the day. It might even be after the stock market closes.

The Dax in Germany is also down. It is down by 1.8%. The Cac 40 in France is down too. It has lost 1.1%.

The Stoxx 600 is a mix of many European companies. It is down by 1.5%.

A big pub company in Britain is called JD Wetherspoon. People said the company needed better leaders. Now, two workers will join the board of directors. This means they will help make important decisions.

The company chose four managers from their pubs. Shareholders and workers said this would be good. They said it would help to have more people with pub experience on the board.

Debbie Whittingham is a manager in the West Midlands. Hudson Simmons is a manager in Sheffield. They will join the board. Two other workers will also help as "associate employee directors."

Tim Martin is the boss of Wetherspoon. He did not like people criticizing the company before. He wrote long letters about it.

But now he says that workers have always given ideas. They talk about things in meetings every week. Now, workers will also be in board meetings. This will help the company keep its good culture.

A group called the High Pay Centre thinks about pay and leaders. They think this is a good thing.

Luke Hildyard works at the High Pay Centre. He said that workers on the board can help the company. They can make customer service and worker relations better.

He thinks it would be better if workers voted for the new directors. Now, the current leaders chose them. He also said workers should have a union. But he thinks this is a good first step for Wetherspoons. It will help workers and shareholders.

In other news, the UK Prime Minister is having a meeting at 2 pm. Keep an eye on this.

text: As Andrew Sparrow points out on the Guardian’s UK politics live blog, there is not usually a cabinet meeting on a Monday, so this is an emergency coronavirus meeting. Dress codes and wine pairings have not yet been released. You can follow updates on the cabinet here: One for the central bank watchers: Germany’s new government has picked a new head of its central bank: “career central banker” Joachim Nagel. Nagel’s predecessor, Jens Weidmann, was perhaps the European Central Bank’s most prominent internal critic -arguing against the stimulus that it has used to prop up the EU economy. (All eurozone central bank heads get a place on the governing council, which sets monetary policy for the bloc.) Nagel, a former Bundesbank board member, will take over on 1 January. Reuters summarised his recent career as: A former board member of the state-owned development bank KfW Bank, Nagel currently works for the Bank for International Settlements, which is often considered the central bank of central banks. Early in his career, he was also a consultant for the SPD, the party that took over government earlier this month and will make the Bundesbank appointment one of its first decisions. Germany’s finance minister under the new coalition government, Christian Lindner, said on Monday: In view of inflation risks, the importance of a stability-oriented monetary policy is growing. He is an experienced personality who ensures continuity at the Bundesbank. The World Economic Forum at Davos has been postponed to the summer because of concerns about the coronavirus variant, it said on Monday. The event, usually held every year at the Swiss ski resort, was scheduled for 17 to 21 January 2022, but will instead happen in “early summer”. In January the World Economic Forum will instead run online meetings. Davos usually serves as an occasion for many of the world’s most powerful people from the realms of business, economics and politics to gather and pontificate about the world’s problems. However, the meeting of thousands of people from all over the world has been difficult to continue during pandemic conditions. The 2021 event was cancelled in favour of online events in the summer.
b1_text:
Okay, here is the rewritten text at a CEFR B1 level:

There is news about a meeting. Andrew Sparrow wrote about it in a blog. The blog is about UK politics. Usually, the cabinet does not meet on Mondays. This meeting is special because of the coronavirus. It is an emergency meeting. We do not know what people will wear or what they will drink.

You can read updates about the cabinet meeting online.

Here is some news about Germany. Germany has a new government. The new government has chosen a new head for the central bank. The new head is Joachim Nagel. He has worked at the central bank for a long time.

The old head was Jens Weidmann. He often disagreed with the European Central Bank. He did not want the bank to help the EU economy.

All the heads of the central banks in Europe are on a council. This council decides about money for all of Europe.

Joachim Nagel used to be on the board of the Bundesbank. He will start his new job on January 1st.

Reuters wrote about Joachim Nagel. He used to work for a bank called KfW Bank. He now works for the Bank for International Settlements. This bank is like a central bank for all central banks. He also helped the SPD party. This party is now in charge of the government. They will choose the new head of the Bundesbank. This is one of the first things they will do.

Christian Lindner is the finance minister in Germany. He said it is important to have stable money. He said Joachim Nagel has experience and will keep things the same at the Bundesbank.

The World Economic Forum in Davos will not happen in January. It will happen in the summer. This is because of the coronavirus. People are worried about the new type of coronavirus.

The meeting was planned for January 17 to 21, 2022. Now it will be in the early summer. In January, there will be online meetings instead.

Many important people go to Davos. They are from business, money, and politics. They talk about the world's problems.

It is hard to have the meeting with many people from all over the world because of the coronavirus. The meeting in 2021 was cancelled. There were online meetings in the summer instead.

text: In a statement, the event’s organisers said: Current pandemic conditions make it extremely difficult to deliver a global in-person meeting. Despite the meeting’s stringent health protocols, the transmissibility of Omicron and its impact on travel and mobility have made deferral necessary. The number of shoppers across British high streets fell over the weekend before Christmas, according to new data from Springboard that show people spurned city centre shopping during what should have been the biggest weekend of the year. Retail footfall was 19% down for the week ending on Saturday compared to the equivalent in 2019, Springboard said - although it was higher than December 2020, when the UK government dramatically u-turned to put in place a Christmas lockdown. Shopping centres fared particularly badly, with footfall down by 27% on 2019, but high streets were also down by a fifth on 2019. Retail parks, which are generally accessed by private car and are often open-air, performed slightly better. Weekend traffic overall fell compared to the previous weekend by 8.5% in Central London and by 6.4% in cities outside of the capital. Diane Wehrle, insights director at Springboard, said: The nervousness of shoppers about making in-person shopping visits inevitably meant that large city centres lost out to smaller high streets, particularly over the weekend when footfall declined from the week before in Central London and large cities outside of the capital whilst rising in market towns. There has been a bit of movement on currency markets as well this morning: sterling is down by 0.4% against the US dollar. One pound will buy $1.3195. That in itself is not a huge move, but it puts the pound perilously close to its lowest level since December 2020, when the UK was facing the prospect of belated Christmas restrictions in the hope of limiting the spread of a new coronavirus variant (a familiar tale). If it drops below $1.3165 it will mark a new low for 2021, an unusual situation considering the Bank of England only just last week shocked markets with an interest rate rise - pre-empting the Federal Reserve. However, the Fed has itself also made it clear that it will tighten the US money supply. The prospect of a series of interest rate rises next year has made the dollar more attractive to investors.
b1_text:
The people who planned the event said something. They said it is hard to have a meeting with people from all over the world now. This is because of the virus.

They had rules to keep people healthy at the meeting. But the new type of virus spreads very easily. It also makes it hard for people to travel. So, they have to move the meeting to a later time.

Many people did not go shopping in British towns before Christmas. This information comes from a group called Springboard. They said people did not shop in city centers. This was during the busiest weekend of the year.

The number of shoppers was less than in 2019. It was 19% less for the week that ended on Saturday. But it was more than in December 2020. At that time, the government changed its mind and had a Christmas lockdown.

Shopping centers did not do well. There were 27% fewer shoppers than in 2019. High streets also had fewer shoppers. It was 20% less than in 2019.

Shopping parks did a little better. People can drive to them and they are often outside.
