There was less traffic on the weekend. Traffic in London went down by 8.5%. Traffic in other cities went down by 6.4%. This is compared to the weekend before.

Diane Wehrle works for Springboard. She said shoppers were worried about going to shops. Big city centers had fewer shoppers. Smaller towns had more shoppers. This was especially true on the weekend. Fewer people went to London and big cities. More people went to smaller towns.

The money market changed a little today. The British pound is worth less than before. It is down 0.4% against the American dollar.

One pound is worth $1.3195. This is not a big change. But the pound is close to its lowest value since December 2020. At that time, the UK might have had Christmas rules to stop the virus.

If the pound goes below $1.3165, it will be the lowest value for 2021. This is surprising. The Bank of England just increased interest rates last week. They did this before the American Federal Reserve.

But the Federal Reserve also said they will make less money available in the US. People think interest rates will increase next year. This makes the American dollar more attractive to people who invest money.

text: Mark Haefele, chief investment officer at UBS Global Wealth Management, said the dollar will be, pace the omicron variant, one of the “winners from global growth” during 2022. There has also been a similar bounce on oil markets. The price of Brent crude, the North Sea benchmark, is still down by 3.3% today - but that is a recovery from earlier. Brent crude futures were down by as much as 5% earlier this morning, with one barrel for February delivery going for as little as $69. It is now back at $71.30. Victoria Scholar, head of investment at interactive investor, an investing platform, said: Heavy selling has hit the oil markets again this week with WTI and Brent crude both shedding more than 3% extending losses after a week in the red with Brent already ending down 2.6% as the Omicron variant continues to spread, weighing on the demand outlook and market sentiment. The Netherlands’ latest lockdown from Sunday sparked investor concerns of fresh restrictions in Europe and the US to curb the spread of Covid, prompting fears of a near-term economic slowdown. Brent crude has shed more than 17% from the October high, trading in a descending trendline and retracing around 70% of its prior gains from the August trough. Kit Juckes, a strategist at Société Générale, a bank, is in a festive mood - albeit the wrong feast. “It’s a lot more like Halloween than Christmas,” he said: Oil prices, equity indices and bond yields are lower on a mix of omicron concerns and Senator Joe Manchin’s announcement that he won’t vote for President Biden’s spending bill. Just over half an hour after the FTSE 100 slumped further, it has just regained a percentage point. It is now down by just 1.3% at 7,179 points, having earlier dropped by as much as 2.2%. European stocks have also recovered somewhat: Germany’s Dax is now down by 2.2% and France’s Cac 40 is down 1.4%. All the usual disclaimers apply at this point in the year: a fair few investors will have shut up shop for the holidays, and few of those who remain will have planned any major moves in the absence of central bank activity.
b1_text:
Mark Haefele works for UBS. He is in charge of investments. He thinks the dollar will do well in 2022. This is because of global growth. The Omicron virus could change things.

Oil prices have also moved up a little. Brent crude is a type of oil. It comes from the North Sea. Its price is down 3.3% today. But it was lower earlier.

This morning, the price of Brent crude was down 5%. One barrel for February cost $69. Now, it costs $71.30.

Victoria Scholar works for an investment company. The company is called interactive investor. She says that people are selling a lot of oil this week. The prices of WTI and Brent crude are both down more than 3%. They were also down last week.

The Omicron virus is spreading. This makes people think there will be less demand for oil. It also makes people feel worried.

The Netherlands has a new lockdown. This started on Sunday. Investors are worried that other countries will also have new rules. They worry that Europe and the US will slow down the spread of Covid. This could make the economy slow down too.

The price of Brent crude is down more than 17% since October. The price has been going down. It has lost about 70% of the money it made since August.

Kit Juckes works for a bank. The bank is called Société Générale. He is not happy. He says it feels like Halloween, not Christmas.

Oil prices are down. Stock prices are down. Bond yields are down. This is because of Omicron. Also, Senator Joe Manchin will not vote for President Biden's spending bill.

The FTSE 100 is a group of big companies. Their value went down. Now, it has gone up a little. It is down by 1.3%. It is at 7,179 points. Earlier, it was down by 2.2%.

Stocks in Europe have also gone up a little. The Dax in Germany is down by 2.2%. The Cac 40 in France is down by 1.4%.

Many investors are not working because of the holidays. The investors who are working are not planning to do much. They are waiting to see what the central banks will do.

text: That means that there will be lower liquidity and fewer buyers to soak up any sales, so moves can be exaggerated. Nevertheless, that is a notable swing over the course of less than an hour. It may have been partly helped by vaccine maker Moderna. It said on Monday (in an interview published at 10am GMT) that a booster dose of its Covid-19 vaccine appeared to offer protection against the omicron variant. Reuters reported: The vaccine maker said the decision to focus on the current vaccine, mRNA-1273, was driven in part by how quickly the recently discovered variant is spreading. The company still plans to develop a vaccine specifically to protect against Omicron, which it hopes to advance into clinical trials early next year. “What we have available right now is 1273,” Dr. Paul Burton, Moderna’s Chief Medical Officer, said in an interview. “It’s highly effective, and it’s extremely safe. I think it will protect people through the coming holiday period and through these winter months, when we’re going to see the most severe pressure of Omicron.” Some detail on how the UK’s shops fared over the last week - usually one of the the strongest of the year: it was not great. Footfall on and near London’s Oxford Street, the country’s biggest shopping district, was 17% below pre-pandemic levels, according to the New West End Company, which represents about 600 shops. Shopping was 5% below the previous weekend, and across the entire week of the 13th December footfall was down by 29% compared with 2019’s figures. Jace Tyrrell, chief executive of the New West End Company, said businesses were “disappointed” with how the weekend went: With less than five days to go until Christmas day and the probabilities of a circuit-breaker lockdown increasingly on the horizon, the retail and leisure sector is now facing a huge amount of financial uncertainty when it should be enjoying a much needed shot in the arm. We are therefore backing the #BusinessBooster campaign and calling on the government to provide urgent and swift financial support. Temporary measures such as a 100% business rate relief for the first quarter of the year, extension of the VAT reduction and introduction of grants could be the difference between viable businesses avoiding closures and job losses in the new year.
b1_text:
It looks like there is less money to buy and sell things. Also, there are not many buyers. So, when things are bought or sold, the prices can change a lot.

Something important happened in less than one hour. The company Moderna, which makes vaccines, may have helped. On Monday, they said their vaccine can protect against the Omicron virus. This was in an interview that started at 10am GMT.

Reuters said that Moderna will use their current vaccine, called mRNA-1273. This is because the Omicron virus is spreading fast.

The company will still make a special vaccine for Omicron. They want to test it early next year.

Dr. Paul Burton from Moderna said that the 1273 vaccine is good now. He said it works well and is very safe. He thinks it will protect people during the holidays and winter. Omicron will be a big problem then.

We also have some news about shops in the UK. Usually, the last week before Christmas is the best week for shops. But this year, it was not good.

Many people shop on Oxford Street in London. It is the biggest shopping area in the country. But this week, there were 17% fewer people than before the virus. This information comes from the New West End Company. They represent about 600 shops.

Shopping was also 5% less than the week before. For the whole week of December 13th, there were 29% fewer people than in 2019.

Jace Tyrrell is the boss of the New West End Company. He said the shops were "disappointed" with the weekend.

Christmas is very close. There is a chance the government might close shops again. This makes it hard for shops to know what to do. They need money now, but they are not getting much.

The New West End Company supports the #BusinessBooster campaign. They want the government to give money to shops quickly.

They want the government to help in a few ways. For example, they want shops to pay less tax at the start of next year. They also want the government to give shops money. This could help shops stay open and keep people from losing their jobs in the new year.

text: The FTSE 100 sell-off has accelerated - it is now down by 2.2%. It has hit the lowest level since the start of December as concern over the spread of the omicron variant ramp up. While the UK government is fielding a lot of questions about parties, the hospitality industry is trying to put the pressure on over the lack of them, given how the current lockdown-lite has affected their bookings. The Guardian’s Joanna Partridge writes: Pubs and restaurants have warned of plummeting sales and “decimated” bookings, as pressure increases on the government to offer urgent financial support to struggling hospitality businesses. The weekend just passed should have been the busiest trading period of the Christmas season, but customers chose to stay away, said Nick Mackenzie, the chief executive of the pub and brewery chain Greene King, which runs 2,700 pubs, restaurants and hotels across the UK. “Demand has dropped, bookings have been decimated, some parts of the country we are 70%, 80% down on 2019, so the situation is pretty unsustainable,” Mackenzie told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme on Monday. Warnings from the government had led to “lockdown in all but name”, Mackenzie said, and he urged the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, to deliver “quick and effective support”. You can read the full report here: Some interesting detail from the notice detailing the reasons for the errors Standard Chartered made. One key reporting problem was caused by a spreadsheet error in which a workers put the wrong sign - so it read as positive rather than negative. Sure, we all make that kind of mistake, except in this case the error meant the calculation was out by a staggering $10bn. That sounds like a very bad day at the office indeed. Standard Chartered will have to pay £46.5m after it failed to cooperate with regulators at the Bank of England. It was a record fine imposed by the Bank’s Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA), which is tasked with overseeing the UK banking sector’s financial stability. The fines came in relation to reporting errors related to movements of US dollars, amid concerns in October 2017 about the outflow of cash.
b1_text:
The FTSE 100 is falling. It is down by 2.2%. This means it is lower than it has been since December. People are worried about the Omicron virus spreading.

The UK government is being asked about parties. Businesses like pubs and restaurants are also asking for help. They are losing money because people are not going out. This is like a small lockdown, but it is hurting their business.

A writer named Joanna Partridge says that pubs and restaurants have much lower sales. Bookings are very bad. They want the government to give them money quickly.

Last weekend was usually the busiest time for Christmas. But people stayed home. Nick Mackenzie runs a company with many pubs and restaurants. He said that business is very bad.

He said that some places are losing 70% or 80% of their money compared to 2019. He told the BBC that this is not good.

Mr. Mackenzie said the government told people to stay home. This made it like a lockdown. He wants the government to help businesses soon.

Standard Chartered bank made a mistake. A worker used the wrong sign in a computer program. This made a big mistake. The mistake was worth $10 billion.

This was a very big mistake. Standard Chartered must pay money because of it. They have to pay £46.5 million. They did not work well with the Bank of England.

The Bank of England gave them a big fine. This bank watches over the money of UK banks. The fine was for mistakes in reporting money. The mistakes were about moving US dollars in 2017.
